NASA spacecraft Ranger 9, equipped to convert its signals into a form suitable for showing on television, brought images of the Moon into ordinary homes before crash-landing.

Led by Jorge Rafael Videla, the Argentine military deposed President Isabel Perón in a coup d'état, established a military junta known as the National Reorganization Process, and began state-sponsored violence against dissidents known as the Dirty War.

The tanker Exxon Valdez began to spill 10.8 million US gal (260,000 bbl; 41,000 m3) of crude oil into Prince William Sound, Alaska, causing one of the most devastating man-made maritime environmental disasters.
Kosovo War: NATO launched air strikes against Yugoslavia, marking the first time NATO has attacked a sovereign country.
James VI of Scotland succeeded to the thrones of England and Ireland as James I, uniting the realms under a single monarch.
Japanese chief minister Ii Naosuke was assassinated by rōnin samurai upset with his role in opening Japan to foreign powers.
German physician Robert Koch announced the discovery of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the pathogen that causes tuberculosis.
The Winton Motor Carriage Company (ad pictured), one of the first American car companies, sold its first unit.
The inaugural Women's Olympiad, the first international women's sports event, opened at the International Sporting Club of Monaco in Monte Carlo.

Irish War of Independence: In Belfast, two men wearing police uniforms broke into a house and murdered a Catholic family in what was believed to be a reprisal for the deaths of two policemen the day before.
One day after making a plea to Salvadoran soldiers to stop carrying out the government's repression, Archbishop Óscar Romero was assassinated while celebrating Mass in San Salvador.
Led by Jigme Thinley, the Bhutan Peace and Prosperity Party won 45 of 47 seats in the country's first National Assembly election.
The co-pilot of Germanwings Flight 9525 deliberately crashed the aircraft in a mass murder–suicide in the French Alps, killing all 150 people on board.
Hundred Years' War: An English fleet led by Richard Fitzalan attacked 250 to 360 French, Flemish and Castilian vessels in the Battle of Margate.
The Tydings–McDuffie Act came into effect, which provided for self-government of the Philippines and for Filipino independence from the United States after a period of ten years.
Members of the German National Movement in Liechtenstein attempted to overthrow the government and provoke Liechtenstein's annexation into Nazi Germany.
Royal assent was given to Prince Edward Island's Provincial Flag Act, which outlined the design of its provincial flag.
Hannah Montana, starring Miley Cyrus as an actress whose alter ego is the titular character, premiered.
According to legend, the city of Venice (in modern Italy) was founded exactly at the stroke of noon with the dedication of the first church, that of San Giacomo at the islet of Rialto.
Robert the Bruce was crowned King of Scotland at Scone.
Hundred Years' War: The English navy captured more than 80 ships and at least 8,000 tuns of wine from an allied French, Castilian and Flemish fleet at the Battle of Margate in the English Channel.
The Council of Pisa, an unrecognized ecumenical conference of the Roman Catholic Church held in an attempt to end the Western Schism, opened in Pisa.
Lord Baltimore, his younger brother Leonard Calvert, and a group of Catholic settlers founded the English colony of Maryland.
France and the United Kingdom signed the Treaty of Amiens, temporarily ending the hostilities between the two during the French Revolutionary Wars.
English Romantic poet Percy Bysshe Shelley was expelled from the University of Oxford for publishing the pamphlet The Necessity of Atheism.
Metropolitan Germanos III of Old Patras raised the Greek flag in the Monastery of Agia Lavra to symbolically mark the beginning of the Greek War of Independence.
First Philippine Republic ended when forced under the command of Brigadier General Frederick Funston, including Macabebe Scouts, captured General Emilio Aguinaldo at Palanan
Following the overthrow of the Russian tsar Nicholas II, Georgia's bishops unilaterally restored the autocephaly of the Georgian Orthodox Church.
The Belarusian People's Republic was established during World War I per the terms of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk, when Belarus was occupied by the German Empire.

The Scottsboro Boys were arrested and charged with rape, leading to a legal case that eventually established legal principles in the United States that criminal defendants are entitled to effective assistance of counsel.
West Germany, Italy, France, the Netherlands, Belgium, and Luxembourg signed the Treaty of Rome, establishing the European Economic Community.
Vietnam War: South Vietnamese forces abandoned a campaign to cut off the Ho Chi Minh trail, which supplied North Vietnamese troops, in Laos.
American computer programmer Ward Cunningham established the first wiki site, the WikiWikiWeb.
A gunman in Seattle, Washington, U.S., entered a rave afterparty and opened fire, killing six and wounding two, before committing suicide.
Constantine was selected as one of the last popes of the Byzantine Papacy.
Byzantine emperor Theodosius III abdicated in favour of Leo the Isaurian after he captured Theodosius's son.
The Yongle Emperor of the Ming dynasty launched the first of his military campaigns against the Mongols, resulting in the fall of the Mongol khan Bunyashiri.
Dutch astronomer Christiaan Huygens discovered Titan, the largest natural satellite of Saturn.
Jacobite risings: A French fleet anchored near Fife Ness as part of a planned French invasion of Britain.
American Revolutionary War: American Patriot forces in Georgia conduct a raid on Tybee Island, with the primary goal of capturing runaway slaves seeking refuge with the British.
War of the Second Coalition: In their second battle in seven days, the French Army of the Danube and Habsburg forces battled for control of the Hegau region.
The Slave Trade Act, which abolished the Atlantic slave trade in the British Empire, received royal assent.
The Scottish National Antarctic Expedition  anchored in the South Orkney Islands with the intention of establishing the first weather station in Antarctic territory.
The Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire in New York City killed 146 sweatshop workers, many of whom could not escape because the doors to the stairwells and exits had been locked.
The appointment of Mehmed Reshid as governor of Diyarbekir, Turkey intensified the genocide of Syriac Christians by pro-Ottoman forces.
World War I: A delayed action bomb left by German troops exploded in the town hall of Bapaume, France, killing 24 soldiers and civilians.

Meteorologists at Tinker Air Force Base in Oklahoma City, United States, issued the world's first tornado forecast after noticing conditions similar to another tornado that had struck five days earlier.
King Faisal of Saudi Arabia was shot and killed by his nephew Faisal bin Musaid.
Wars of the Roses: A formal reconciliation ceremony between the Lancastrians and Yorkists led to a brief period of peace.
Enrico Fermi published his discovery of neutron-induced radioactivity, for which he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics.
The Soviet Union began mass deportations of more than 90,000 "undesirable" people from the Baltic states to Siberia.
Pope John XIX crowned Conrad II as Holy Roman Emperor.
Saladin was inaugurated as vizier of Egypt.

War of the Breton Succession: Thirty knights and squires each from France and England fought to determine who would rule the Duchy of Brittany, later celebrated as a noble display of the ideals of chivalry.
Utrecht University, one of the oldest universities in the Netherlands and one of the largest in Europe, was established.
The Book of Mormon, the defining sacred text of the Latter Day Saint movement, was first published.
The Paris Commune was formally established in Paris.
Domnitor Carol I was proclaimed the first King of Romania, beginning the Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen dynasty.
The first episode of The Young and the Restless was broadcast, eventually becoming the most watched daytime drama on American television from 1988 onwards.
A group of peasant women in Chamoli district, Uttarakhand, India, surrounded trees in order to prevent loggers from felling them, giving rise to the Chipko movement.
Four days before the scheduled opening of Japan's Narita International Airport, a group of protesters destroyed much of the equipment in the control tower with Molotov cocktails.
With the signing of a peace treaty in Washington, D.C., Egypt became the first Arab country officially to recognize Israel.
Groundbreaking ceremony for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial was held.
The Melissa computer virus was released, infecting email systems around the world.
The Taiwanese government called on 1 million Taiwanese to demonstrate in Taipei, in opposition to China's Anti-Secession Law.
Byzantine emperor Maurice proclaimed his son Theodosius as his co-emperor.
William Caxton printed the first English translation of Aesop's Fables.
A Dutch military expedition was launched to bombard Banda Aceh, the capital of the Aceh Sultanate in present-day Indonesia, beginning the Aceh War.
Perceiving that the Canadian government was failing to protect their rights, the Métis people led by Louis Riel began the North-West Rebellion.
An explosion at the Brunner Mine in New Zealand killed 65 coal miners in the country's deadliest mining accident.
First Balkan War: After a five-month siege, Bulgarian and Serbian forces (artillery pictured) captured the Ottoman city of Adrianople.
First World War: Attempting to advance into Palestine, the British were defeated by Ottoman troops at the First Battle of Gaza.
The American tanker Dixie Arrow is torpedoed and sunk off Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, by the German U-boat U-71.
Jonas Salk announced the successful test of his polio vaccine on a small group of adults and children.
The Biological Weapons Convention, the first multilateral disarmament treaty banning the production of an entire category of weapons, entered into force.
Police in Rancho Santa Fe, California, discovered the bodies of 39 members of the religious group Heaven's Gate who had died in an apparent cult suicide.
A prototype of the Tesla Model S, one of the most influential electric cars in history, was unveiled.
An explosion, allegedly caused by a North Korean torpedo, sank the South Korean warship ROKS Cheonan near Baengnyeongdo in the Yellow Sea, killing 46 sailors.
Reconquista: The Muslim city of Algeciras surrendered after a 21-month siege and was incorporated into the Kingdom of Castile.
The Spanish ship San José ran aground onto coasts controlled by the indigenous Cunco people, who subsequently killed the crew.
The Safavid Empire began a four-year occupation of the Ottoman city of Basra on the Persian Gulf.
The Boston Gazette printed a cartoon coining the term "gerrymander", named after Governor Elbridge Gerry, who approved the legislation that created oddly shaped electoral districts.
Nationalist forces began their final offensive of the Spanish Civil War, at the end of which they controlled almost the entire country.
A jury began deliberations in the trial of Jack Kevorkian, an American practitioner of physician-assisted suicide who was charged with murder in the death of a terminally ill patient.
Charles Watson-Wentworth, 2nd Marquess of Rockingham, a leading British Whig Party statesman, began his second non-consecutive term as prime minister of Great Britain.
To protect American merchant ships from Barbary pirates, Congress passed the Naval Act to authorize the building of six frigates, which eventually became the U.S. Navy.
In central Alabama, U.S. and Native American forces under General Andrew Jackson defeated the Creek at the Battle of Horseshoe Bend.
Explorer Lafayette Bunnell and other members of the Mariposa Battalion became the non-indigenous discoverers of California's Yosemite Valley.
Mary Mallon, the first person to be identified as an asymptomatic carrier of typhoid fever, was placed into quarantine in New York City, where she spent the rest of her life.
The 9.2 Mw Good Friday earthquake, the strongest in U.S. history, and subsequent tsunamis devastated Anchorage, Alaska, killing over 130 people.
Two Boeing 747 airliners collided on a foggy runway  at Los Rodeos Airport on the island of Tenerife, killing 583 people in the worst aircraft accident in aviation history.
Jiang Zemin succeeded Yang Shangkun to become President of the People's Republic of China.
A suicide bomber killed at least 48 people during Friday prayer at a mosque in Jamrud, Pakistan.
The first of four destructive earthquakes struck southern Italy, destroying an estimated 10,000 homes.
At least 425 Texian prisoners of war were executed in the Goliad massacre, under orders from Mexican president Antonio López de Santa Anna.
San Diego, the first European settlement in present-day California, was incorporated as a city.
World War II: A group of Serbian-nationalist officers of the Royal Yugoslav Air Force carried out a coup d'état after Yugoslavia joined the Axis powers.
World War II: The United States Army Air Forces began Operation Starvation, laying naval mines in many of Japan's vital water routes and ports to disrupt enemy shipping.
Nikita Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, assumed the office of premier.
Construction of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System, an oil pipeline spanning the length of Alaska, began.
The Washington Metro, the second-busiest rapid transit system in the U.S., opened to commuters.
Brothers Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt failed in their attempt to corner the world silver market, causing panic in commodity and futures exchanges.
The Solidarity movement in Poland staged a warning strike, the largest in the history of the Eastern Bloc, in which at least 12 million Poles walked off their jobs for four hours.

Second Intifada: A suicide bomber killed around 30 Israeli civilians and injured about 140 others in Netanya, triggering Operation Defensive Shield, a large-scale counter-terrorist military incursion into the West Bank.
A failure of the dam holding Situ Gintung, an artificial lake in Tangerang, Indonesia, caused floods that killed at least 100 people.
Himeji Castle, the largest and most visited Japanese castle, re-opened after five years of restoration work.
Forty people are killed in a fire at a migrant detention facility in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico.
Outraged by a jury's decision to convict a man of manslaughter instead of murder, a mob in Cincinnati, Ohio, began three days of rioting.
Philippine–American War: American forces defeated troops commanded by Philippine president Emilio Aguinaldo at the Battle of Marilao River.

The Food and Drug Administration approved the drug sildenafil (chemical structure pictured), better known by the trade name Viagra, as the first treatment approved in the United States for erectile dysfunction.
NATO bombing of Yugoslavia: A U.S. Air Force F-117 stealth aircraft was shot down by a Yugoslav Army unit.
North Macedonia became a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
Spanish explorer Juan Bautista de Anza selected the site for the Presidio of San Francisco, the northernmost outpost of the Spanish Empire in the New World.
Partitions of Poland: The Duchy of Courland, a northern fief of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, ceased to exist and became part of the Russian Empire.
War of 1812: Off the coast of Valparaíso, Chile, two Royal Navy ships easily captured two American ones.
The Vienna Philharmonic held its first concert, conducted by Otto Nicolai.
American Civil War: An invasion of the New Mexico Territory by the Confederate States Army was halted by Union forces at the Battle of Glorieta Pass.
French aviator Henri Fabre's floatplane, the Fabre Hydravion, became the first aircraft to take off from water under its own power at the Étang de Berre near Martigues in southern France.
An outbreak of 37 tornadoes across the Midwestern and Southern United States left more than 380 people dead.
Fellow movie stars, Douglas Fairbanks marries Mary Pickford in Los Angeles, California to become America's first Hollywood supercouple.
After the Dalai Lama fled Tibet, China installed the Panchen Lama as the head of the government.
Radio Caroline began broadcasting as a pirate radio station from a boat anchored in international waters.

A partial core meltdown of the Three Mile Island Nuclear Generating Station near Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, resulted in the release of an estimated 43,000 curies (1.59 PBq) of radioactive krypton to the environment.
The Nias–Simeulue earthquake hit the island of Sumatra in Indonesia, killing approximately 1,300 people.
Invasion of Iraq: In a friendly fire incident, two members of the United States Air Force attacked the United Kingdom's Blues and Royals regiment, killing one soldier and injuring five.
The Praetorian Guard assassinated Roman emperor Pertinax and sold the imperial office in an auction to Didius Julianus (coin pictured).
World War I: British and Australian troops defeated German forces at the First Battle of Dernancourt in northern France.
After an on-board fire that may have been the first incident of airliner sabotage, the Imperial Airways biplane City of Liverpool broke apart in mid-air, killing fifteen people.
In the Tragedy of Otranto, the Italian Navy vessel Sibilla collided with the Albanian civilian vessel Kateri i Radës, causing the latter to sink and leading to dozens of deaths.
A siege of a hotel in Mogadishu by al-Shabaab militants, which began the previous day and killed at least 20 people, ended with the Somali Armed Forces recapturing the premises.
American Dad! aired it's critically acclaimed two-hundredth episode.
German astronomer Heinrich Wilhelm Matthias Olbers discovered Pallas, the second asteroid to be identified, but at the time considered to be a planet.
The Nazi propaganda film Triumph of the Will, directed by Leni Riefenstahl, premiered in Berlin.
Second World War: The port of Saint-Nazaire in German-occupied France was disabled  by British naval forces (ship pictured).
The US Department of State released the Acheson–Lilienthal Report, a proposal for the international control of nuclear weapons.
British prime minister James Callaghan was defeated by one vote in a vote of no confidence after his government struggled to cope with widespread strikes during the Winter of Discontent.
Kosovo War: Serbian police and special forces killed around 93 Kosovo Albanians in the village of Izbica.
New Sweden, near Delaware Bay, was founded as the first Swedish colony in the Americas.
U.S. president Thomas Jefferson authorized the construction of the Cumberland Road, one of the first major improved highways in the United States that was built by the federal government.
At the Diet of Porvoo, the Four Estates of Finland pledged allegiance to Tsar Alexander I of Russia, commencing the secession of the Grand Duchy of Finland from Sweden.
Bosniak general Husein Gradaščević began an uprising against Sultan Mahmud II and the Ottoman Empire.
The first edition of The Irish Times was published.
The United Kingdom annexed the Punjab region.
The Royal Albert Hall in Albertopolis, London, was officially opened by Queen Victoria.
The M1911 pistol, developed by American firearms designer John Browning, became the standard-issue sidearm in the United States Army.
Second World War: The Royal Air Force completed a bombing raid on Lübeck, the first major success for RAF Bomber Command against a German city.
World War II: The German 4th Army was almost completely destroyed by the Soviet Red Army at the Heiligenbeil Pocket in East Prussia.
Instituto Tecnológico Autónomo de México, one of Mexico's leading universities, was founded.
The New People's Army, the armed wing of the Communist Party of the Philippines, was formed.
Vietnam War: The United States ended Operation Barrel Roll, a covert bombing campaign in Laos to help stem an increasing tide of People's Army of Vietnam and Pathet Lao offensives.
Viking expansion: Viking raiders, possibly led by the legendary Ragnar Lodbrok, plundered and occupied Paris (depicted), holding the city for a large ransom.
After an eight-year siege, the Ottoman Empire captured the city of Thessalonica from the Republic of Venice.
Wars of the Roses: Yorkist troops defeated Lancastrian forces in Yorkshire at the Battle of Towton, one of the largest land battles ever fought in England.
William Matthews was ordained as the first Catholic priest born in British America.
German astronomer Heinrich Wilhelm Matthias Olbers discovered Vesta, the brightest asteroid and second-most massive body in the asteroid belt.

American Civil War: The Appomattox campaign opened with the Battle of Lewis's Farm, in which the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia was forced into a series of retreats that would culminate in their surrender.
The North American Regional Broadcasting Agreement to define technical standards for AM band radio stations came into effect.
Second World War: British and Australian ships defeated Italian Regia Marina vessels at the Battle of Cape Matapan.
The King and I, a musical about Mongkut of Siam by Rodgers and Hammerstein, premiered on Broadway.
The funeral of Yuri Gagarin, the first man in space, began in Moscow with tens of thousands of people in attendance.
A group of farmers in the Chinese province of Shaanxi discovered a vast collection of terracotta statues depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first emperor of China.
Jeff Beck released Blow by Blow, his most successful album in the U.S., reaching the top five and selling over one million copies.
Dick Beardsley and Inge Simonsen jointly won the Men's Elite Race and Joyce Smith won the Women's Elite Race in the inaugural London Marathon.
Queen Elizabeth II granted royal assent to the Canada Act 1982, which ended any remaining constitutional dependence of Canada on the United Kingdom by a process known as patriation.
The Chamoli earthquake, one of the strongest to hit the foothills of the Himalayas in more than 90 years, killed at least 100 people.
Islamist separatists of the Caucasus Emirate detonated two bombs on the Moscow Metro, killing 40 people and injuring 102 others.
British prime minister Theresa May invoked Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union, formally beginning the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union.
Wars of the Roses: The Yorkists defeated the Lancastrian army at the Battle of Towton, allowing Edward IV to secure the English throne.
The Knights of Columbus, the world's largest Catholic fraternal service organization, was founded by Michael J. McGivney in New Haven, Connecticut, U.S.
NASA's Mariner 10 became the first space probe to make a flyby of Mercury.
The first same-sex marriages in England and Wales took place following the passage of the Marriage (Same Sex Couples) Act 2013.
Sicilians began to rebel against the rule of the Angevin King Charles I of Naples, starting the War of the Sicilian Vespers.
American physician Crawford Long became the first person to use diethyl ether as an anesthetic in a surgical procedure.
A committee of the German Society of Chemistry invited other national scientific organizations to appoint delegates to form the International Committee on Atomic Weights.
Second Sino-Japanese War: Wang Jingwei was officially installed by Japan as head of a puppet state in China.
The Yonge–University–Spadina line, the first subway in Canada and the busiest in Toronto, opened.
The Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, an international treaty aimed against the illicit manufacture and trafficking of narcotic drugs, was signed.
Jeopardy!, the popular American game show created by Merv Griffin, made its debut on the NBC television network.
Aboard Soyuz TMA-8, on a mission to the International Space Station, Marcos Pontes became the first Brazilian in space.
British chemist William Crookes published his discovery of thallium using flame spectroscopy.
U.S. secretary of state William H. Seward negotiated the purchase of Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
Four days of inter-ethnic clashes broke out in Baku, Azerbaijan, resulting in about 12,000 deaths.
The Australian Air Corps was disbanded, to be replaced the following day by the Australian Air Force.
Usmar Ismail began shooting Darah dan Doa, widely recognised as the first Indonesian film.
Vietnam War: North Vietnamese forces began the Easter Offensive in an attempt to gain as much territory and destroy as many South Vietnamese units as possible.
John Hinckley Jr. shot and wounded U.S. president Ronald Reagan and three others outside the Washington Hilton (immediate aftermath pictured).
Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother, widow of King George VI and mother of Queen Elizabeth II, died at Royal Lodge aged 101.
The United States merged East Florida and West Florida to create the Florida Territory.
Sultan Abd al-Hafid signed the Treaty of Fes (depicted), making Morocco a French protectorate.
Annie Hall had its first screening at the LA Film Festival; it was voted the funniest screenplay ever by members of the Writers Guild of America.
The Manawan Police Academy in Lahore, Pakistan, was attacked and held for several hours by 12 gunmen, resulting in 16 deaths and 95 injuries.
The Catholic Monarchs of Spain issued the Alhambra Decree, ordering all Jews to convert to Christianity or be expelled from the country.

A sermon on The Nature of the Kingdom of Christ by Benjamin Hoadly, the Bishop of Bangor, ignited the Bangorian Controversy, a theological argument within the Church of England about whether the church should have any disciplinary authority.
English explorer James Cook landed on Vancouver Island and claimed it for Great Britain.
The Eiffel Tower in Paris, France, was inaugurated.

New Zealand inventor Richard Pearse reportedly flew in one of the first powered flying machines for a distance of several hundred metres, about nine months before the Wright brothers flew their Wright Flyer.
The Danish West Indies became the U.S. Virgin Islands after the United States paid Denmark US$25 million for the Caribbean islands.
A TWA Fokker trimotor crashed in Chase County, Kansas, U.S., and killed eight people, including football coach Knute Rockne, stimulating advances in aircraft design and development.
The first UNIVAC I, the first commercial computer made in the United States, was delivered to the United States Census Bureau.
Nine Japanese communists armed with samurai swords and pipe bombs hijacked Japan Airlines Flight 351 en route from Tokyo to Fukuoka.
French abbot Bernard of Clairvaux preached a sermon to a crowd at a council in Vézelay, with King Louis VII in attendance, urging the necessity of a Second Crusade.
Ferdinand Magellan and members of his crew participated in the first Catholic Mass in the Philippines.
Lisbon experienced its second major earthquake in six years, with effects felt as far north as Scotland.
After fighting through the night, the French Navy ship of the line Guillaume Tell surrendered to a British squadron in the Malta Channel.
Philippine–American War: Malolos, capital of the First Philippine Republic, was captured by American forces.
A magnitude 7.2 earthquake struck the Black Sea, the most powerful ever recorded in the area.
Six English towns amalgamated to form a single county borough called Stoke-on-Trent, the first union of its type.
Arnold Schoenberg conducted the Vienna Concert Society in a concert of expressionist music that so shocked the audience that they began to riot.
The Australian Air Force was formed, replacing the short-lived Australian Air Corps and separating it from the Army.
To avoid government censorship, Hollywood movie studios instituted their own set of industry censorship guidelines, popularly known as the Hays Code.
Second World War: Because of a mutiny by Indian soldiers against their British officers, Japanese troops captured Christmas Island without any resistance.
USS Missouri, the last active United States Navy battleship, was decommissioned in Long Beach, California.

American singer-songwriter Selena, known as the "queen of Tejano music", was murdered by the president of her fan club, Yolanda Saldívar, in Corpus Christi, Texas, deeply affecting the Latino community.
Nikol Pashinyan began his protest walk, starting in the city of Gyumri, opening the 2018 Armenian revolution.
A tornado causes the collapse of a venue hosting a sold-out concert in Belvidere, Illinois, United States, resulting in one death and 48 injuries.
U.S. Navy Commodore Matthew C. Perry (Japanese depiction pictured) and the Tokugawa shogunate signed the Convention of Kanagawa, forcing the opening of Japanese ports to American trade.
After a two-week escape journey from Tibet, the 14th Dalai Lama reached the Tawang Monastery in Arunachal Pradesh in India.
The Brazilian Armed Forces overthrew President João Goulart, establishing a military dictatorship that lasted 21 years.
The Old National Library Building in Singapore was closed to make way for a tunnel, despite widespread protests.
Dutch Revolt: The Geuzen captured the undefended town of Brielle from Fernando Álvarez de Toledo, providing the first foothold on land for the rebels.
Frederick Muhlenberg became the first Speaker of the United States House of Representatives.
Hard Times, the tenth novel by Charles Dickens, was released.
The first ever all-Ireland hurling final was played in Birr, County Offaly.
William Wrigley Jr. founded the Wrigley Company, the world's largest manufacturer and marketer of chewing gum.
The Reserve Bank of India, the nation's central bank, was founded during the British Raj.
The town of Schaffhausen in Switzerland was accidentally bombed by United States aircraft.
The main mutiny in a series of mutinies of the Royal New Zealand Navy began.
Apple Computer was originally founded to sell the Apple I, an early personal computer sold as kits.
The Philippine College of Commerce became a chartered state university and renamed the Polytechnic University of the Philippines.
The government of Nova Scotia amalgamated the City of Halifax and the over 200 communities around the area to create the Halifax Regional Municipality.
Canada's newest territory Nunavut came into being.
Google launched Gmail, now the most widely used web mail system.
Several British policing agencies joined together to become the Serious Organised Crime Agency.
Richard Marshal, Earl of Pembroke, was defeated by knights loyal to King Henry III of England at the Battle of the Curragh in County Kildare, Ireland.
Robert Winchelsey left England for Rome to be consecrated Archbishop of Canterbury, but a papal vacancy delayed the ceremony.
American Civil War: The Union Army under Major General Philip Sheridan inflicted more than 2,900 casualties on the Confederates at the Battle of Five Forks.
The Duke of Buckingham opened the first section of the Brill Tramway, a short railway line to transport goods between his lands and the national rail network.
The Inland Customs Line, established by the British for the collection of the salt tax in India, was abandoned.
Under the South Seas Mandate, Japan set up a government in Koror, precipitating large-scale Japanese settlement in Palau.
English cricketer Wally Hammond set a record for the highest individual score in Test cricket of 336 not out during a match against New Zealand.
Soviet border guards opened fire on civilians attempting to cross the border from the Soviet Union to Romania near Fântâna Albă, killing between 44 and 3,000 people.
Israel enacted a citizenship law, prior to which the country technically had no citizens.
On Her Majesty's Secret Service, the tenth novel of Ian Fleming's James Bond series, was released in the United Kingdom.
The Hawker Siddeley Harrier, the first operational fighter aircraft with V/STOL capabilities, entered service with the Royal Air Force.
U.S. president Richard Nixon signed the Public Health Cigarette Smoking Act into law, requiring that a prominent warning by the surgeon general be placed on cigarette packages.
The American Motors Corporation introduced its Gremlin, promoted as America's first subcompact car.
The longest prison riot in British penal history began at Strangeways Prison in Manchester, lasting 25 days.
Same-sex marriage in the Netherlands was legalized, making it the first country to do so.
A band of warriors led by Niels Ebbesen killed Count Gerhard III, ending Holstein rule in Denmark.
Mexican Texans met at San Felipe de Austin to begin the Convention of 1833.
The United Kingdom established the Royal Air Force (badge depicted), near the end of the First World War.
The British Army's Mobile Defence Corps, intended to assist with civil defence after a nuclear attack, was established by royal warrant.
An American Lockheed EP-3 and a Chinese Shenyang J-8 collided in mid-air off Hainan, resulting in an international dispute between the two countries.
A naval fleet led by Commodore William James of the East India Company captured the fortress Suvarnadurg from the Marathas.
By the Coinage Act, the United States Mint was founded and U.S. currency was decimalized.
Russia and the Ottoman Empire signed the Treaty of Constantinople, establishing the Septinsular Republic, the first autonomous Greek state in more than 300 years.
War of the Second Coalition: British forces led by Vice Admiral Horatio Nelson defeated the Dano-Norwegian fleet at the Battle of Copenhagen.
About 5,000 people in Richmond, Virginia, mostly poor women, rioted in protest of the high price of bread (depicted).
North-West Rebellion: Led by Wandering Spirit, young Cree warriors attacked the village of Frog Lake, North-West Territories (now in Alberta), where they killed nine settlers.

Brazil established diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, but maintained a neutral relationship during the Cold War that was limited to commercial trade and cooperation agreements of minimal importance.
As the World Turns premiered on American television as the first half-hour soap opera.
The first official panda crossing opened outside London Waterloo station.
The LEXIS computer-assisted legal research service launched as a continuation of an experiment organized by the Ohio State Bar in 1967.
Norodom Sihanouk resigned as leader of Cambodia and was arrested by the Khmer Rouge.
More than 60 tornadoes touched down in the central United States, killing 27 people and causing about $1.1 billion in damage.
Spanish conquistador Juan Ponce de León sighted land in North America, naming the area La Florida.
The first modern Italian Parliament is opened in Turin, following the annexation of Central Italy into the Kingdom of Sardinia.
American Civil War: On the third attempt, Union forces captured Petersburg, Virginia, although Confederate officials and most of their remaining troops were able to escape.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics conducted the first national census of the country.

John Gotti, the head of the Gambino crime family of New York City, was convicted of racketeering, murder, conspiracy to commit murder, loansharking, obstruction of justice, illegal gambling, and tax evasion.
Second Intifada: Palestinian militants sought refuge from advancing Israeli forces in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, beginning a month-long siege.
A gunman shot at people inside Oikos University, a Korean Christian college in Oakland, California, leaving seven people dead and three injured.
Gunmen attacked Garissa University College in Kenya, killing 148 people and wounding 79 others.
2001: A Space Odyssey, the epic science fiction film produced and directed by Stanley Kubrick, premiered at the Uptown Theater in Washington, D.C.
Spores of anthrax were accidentally released from a military research facility near the city of Sverdlovsk, causing at least 68 deaths.
Argentine special forces invaded the Falkland Islands, sparking the Falklands War against the United Kingdom.
Bosnian War: At least 48 civilians were massacred in the town of Bijeljina in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Six elderly men burgled a safe-deposit facility in Hatton Garden, London, and stole items worth up to an estimated £14 million.
Joseph Stalin became the first general secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
Richard Hauptmann was executed in the electric chair for the kidnapping and murder of the "Lindbergh baby".
Philippine resistance against Japan: Cebuano fishermen discovered the Koga papers after a plane crash killed Admiral Mineichi Koga, commander-in-chief of the Imperial Japanese Navy's Combined Fleet.
Imperial Japanese Army officer Masaharu Homma was executed for war crimes committed during the Bataan Death March.
The Marshall Plan, an economic recovery program established by U.S. Secretary of State George Marshall to assist the post-World War II re-building of Europe, was signed into law.
Division of Korea: A communist uprising began on Jeju Island, eventually leading to thousands of deaths and atrocities committed by both sides.
An individual Leadbeater's possum, thought to have been extinct for over 50 years, was discovered in New South Wales, Australia.
Luna 10 entered orbit around the Moon, becoming the first space probe to orbit an astronomical body other than Earth.
The Japanese tokusatsu television series Kamen Rider premiered, the first property in a long-running media franchise.
On a New York City street, Motorola researcher Martin Cooper made the first public call on a handheld mobile phone.
The Super Outbreak of 148 tornadoes began, killing at least 315 people and injuring 5,484 in 13 US states at the end of a very strong La Niña event.
The Osborne 1, the first successful portable computer, was unveiled at the West Coast Computer Faire in San Francisco.
Texas law enforcement authorities raided  the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints' YFZ Ranch, eventually removing 533 women and children from the premises.
Henry II of France and Philip II of Spain signed the second treaty of Cateau-Cambrésis, ending the Italian War of 1551–1559.
Robert Walpole took office as First Lord of the Treasury, Chancellor of the Exchequer and Leader of the House of Commons, becoming the first de facto prime minister of Great Britain.
The Pony Express, a mail service that became the most direct means of long-distance communication across the United States before the first transcontinental telegraph, began operation.
Emma Elizabeth Smith was killed in the first of eleven unsolved murders of women that took place in or near the impoverished Whitechapel district in the East End of London.
The libel trial instigated by Irish author Oscar Wilde began, eventually resulting in his arrest, trial and imprisonment on charges of gross indecency.
Lord Clydesdale and David McIntyre undertook the first successful flight over Mount Everest.
In United States v. Microsoft Corp., Microsoft was found to have violated antitrust law by bundling the web browser Internet Explorer with its Windows operating system.
Apple Inc. released the first generation iPad, a tablet computer.
The first news stories on the Panama Papers were published, revealing that shell corporations represented by the Panamanian law firm Mossack Fonseca had been used for illegal purposes.
Edward the Confessor, usually considered to be the last king of the House of Wessex, was crowned King of England.
Aboard Soyuz T-11, Rakesh Sharma became the first Indian to be launched into space.
A U.S. Air Force CT-43 crashed into a mountainside while attempting an instrument approach to Dubrovnik Airport in Croatia, killing all 35 people on board, including Secretary of Commerce Ron Brown.
A gunman opened fire at the American Civic Association in Binghamton, New York, U.S., killing thirteen and wounding four before committing suicide.
The northeastern section of Buenos Aires Province, Argentina, experienced several flash floods that killed at least 100 people.
The University of Basel was opened as Switzerland's first university.
Charles II of England issued the Declaration of Breda, describing his conditions for the Restoration of the crown of England.
Philip Astley set up the first modern amphitheatre for the display of horse riding tricks in Lambeth, London, the origin of the modern circus.
French naturalist Georges Cuvier delivered a lecture at the National Museum of Natural History on living and fossil remains of elephants and related species, founding the science of paleontology.
Napoleon abdicated as Emperor of the French and named his son Napoleon II to replace him.
Russian tsar Alexander II narrowly survived an assassination attempt by Dmitry Karakozov.
World War II: The U.S. Third Army captured the German city of Kassel after three days of fighting.
Surgeons Denton Cooley and Domingo Liotta implanted the first total artificial heart.
A C-141, dubbed the Hanoi Taxi, flew the last mission of Operation Homecoming to return American prisoners of war from Vietnam.
Deposed Pakistani prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was controversially executed for authorising the murder of a political opponent.
The current flag of Hong Kong was adopted for post-colonial use during the Third Session of the Seventh National People's Congress.
The Angolan government and UNITA rebels signed a memorandum of understanding, agreeing to observe the 1994 Lusaka Protocol and ending the 26-year-long Angolan Civil War.
The Byzantine Empire and the Republic of Venice signed a five-year peace treaty.

William Henry Harrison became the first U.S. president to die in office, sparking a brief constitutional crisis regarding questions of presidential succession that were unanswered by the U.S. Constitution.
The Kennel Club, the world's oldest kennel club, was founded in the United Kingdom after Sewallis Shirley became frustrated by trying to organise dog shows without a consistent set of rules.
American civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee.
A year after the completion of the second of the complex's twin towers, the World Trade Center in New York City was officially dedicated.
Bill Gates and Paul Allen founded Microsoft in Albuquerque, New Mexico, to develop and sell BASIC interpreters for the Altair 8800.
Vietnam War: On a mission to evacuate children from South Vietnam, a U.S. Air Force plane crash-landed at Tan Son Nhut Air Base, killing 78 children and 60 others.
Evan Mecham, Governor of Arizona, was removed from office after being convicted in his impeachment trial.
A building collapsed on tribal land in Thane in Maharashtra, India, causing 74 deaths.
The Komnenos dynasty came to full power with the coronation of Alexios I Komnenos as Byzantine emperor.
Bryant's Minstrels premiered the minstrel song "Dixie" in New York City as part of their blackface show.
An earthquake hit the Kangra Valley in India, killing at least 20,000 people and destroying 100,000 buildings.

Twelve nations signed the North Atlantic Treaty, establishing NATO, an international military alliance whereby its member states agree to mutual defense in response to an attack by any external party.

Northern Crusades: In the Battle on the Ice, Novgorod forces led by Alexander Nevsky rebuffed an invasion attempt by the Teutonic Knights at Lake Peipus on the present-day border of Estonia and Russia.
A covenant of nobles in the Habsburg Netherlands presented Governor Margaret of Parma a petition to suspend the Spanish Inquisition in the Netherlands.
Forces of the Japanese feudal domain of Satsuma captured the castle on Ryukyu Island, beginning the process that turned the Ryukyu Kingdom into a vassal state under Satsuma.
Dutch explorer Jacob Roggeveen became the first European to land on Easter Island.
American Civil War: Union Maj. Gen. George B. McClellan's Army of the Potomac engaged Confederate forces led by Maj. Gen. John B. Magruder at the Battle of Yorktown in Yorktown, Virginia.
Archaeologists led by Arthur Evans in Knossos, Crete, discovered a large cache of clay tablets with a script used for writing Mycenaean Greek now known as Linear B.

World War II: Carrier-based aircraft of the Imperial Japanese Navy conducted the Easter Sunday Raid on Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) and the British Eastern Fleet in an attempt to drive the Commonwealth naval force from the Indian Ocean.
In one of the first live Canadian national television broadcasts, Ripple Rock, an underwater mountain in Discovery Passage, British Columbia, was destroyed in a planned explosion.
The Tiananmen Incident, a protest against the Chinese regime triggered by the death of Premier Zhou Enlai near the end of the Cultural Revolution, took place in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
Bosnian War: Unidentified gunmen killed two people while firing upon a large crowd of anti-war protesters in Sarajevo, marking the start of the four-year-long Siege of Sarajevo.
The Statute of Anne, the first legislation in Great Britain providing for copyright regulated by the government and courts, received royal assent and entered into force five days later.
Birkenhead Park, generally acknowledged as the world's first publicly funded civic park, opened in Birkenhead, England.

New Zealand Wars: The invasion of the Waikato ended after the Kīngitanga forces of King Tāwhiao abandoned their pā at Te Tiki o te Ihingarangi and migrated east to what became known as the King Country.
A spectator stand collapsed during a football match at Ibrox Park in Govan, Scotland, killing 25 supporters and injuring more than 500 others.
Nazi sympathisers attempted to kidnap two German-Jewish filmmakers in Liechtenstein.
An F5 tornado struck Tupelo, Mississippi, killing at least 216 people during one of the deadliest tornado outbreaks in U.S. history.
Aware that he was slowing down both physically and mentally in his old age, Winston Churchill retired as prime minister of the United Kingdom.
During the Buddhist Uprising, South Vietnamese military prime minister Nguyễn Cao Kỳ personally attempted to lead the capture of the restive city of Đà Nẵng before backing down.
Faculty members, clerical workers, and librarians at Boston University went on strike.
The Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, then the world's longest suspension bridge, linking Awaji Island and Kobe in Japan, opened to traffic.

Fan violence broke out before a UEFA Cup semifinal in Istanbul, Turkey, resulting in two Leeds United supporters being stabbed to death and Galatasaray supporters being banned from attending the second leg in England.
In the first reported data breach, 250,000 social security numbers collected by the State of California were stolen from a data center.
An explosion at a coal mine in West Virginia killed 29 miners in the United States' worst mining disaster in 40 years.
Agents with the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement raided a slaughterhouse in Tennessee, detaining nearly 100 Hispanic workers in one of the largest immigration raids in the history of the U.S.
The Fatimid Caliphate began a second unsuccessful invasion of Egypt, then under Abbasid rule.
Pocahontas, a Native American woman, married English colonist John Rolfe, leading to a period of peace between the Powhatan people and the inhabitants of Jamestown, Virginia.
Siegfried Lederer, a Czech Jew, escaped from Auschwitz with the aid of an SS officer who opposed the Holocaust.
The Libyan secret service bombed a discotheque in West Berlin, resulting in three deaths and 229 others injured.

The North Korean satellite Kwangmyŏngsŏng-2 was launched from the Tonghae Satellite Launching Ground and passed over Japan, sparking concerns it may have been a trial run of technology that could be used to launch intercontinental ballistic missiles.
Gothic Wars: A Roman army led by Stilicho turned back an attempted Gothic invasion of Italy led by Alaric I.
The Declaration of Arbroath, a declaration of Scottish independence, was adopted.
An estimated ML5.3–5.9 earthquake struck the Strait of Dover, one of the largest earthquakes in the recorded history of England, Flanders and Northern France.
Rama I succeeded King Taksin of Siam, founding the Chakri Dynasty.
French Revolution: The Committee of Public Safety was established, and would become the de facto executive government during the forthcoming Reign of Terror.
The Grand Army of the Republic, a fraternal organization composed of veterans of the Union Army who had served in the American Civil War, was founded in Decatur, Illinois.
The Charter Oath, which stated the main aims and methods of action of the new Meiji era of Japan, was promulgated in Kyoto.
Vancouver, one of British Columbia's youngest cities, was incorporated.
The Salt Lake Temple, the largest of more than 140 temples of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, was dedicated in Salt Lake City.
The first modern Olympic Games opened in Athens.
American explorer Robert Peary allegedly became the first person to reach the North Pole; his claim was accepted for many years, although modern research has determined that he most likely did not.
World War I: After more than two and a half years of efforts by President Woodrow Wilson to maintain neutrality, the United States declared war on Germany.
The first Tony Awards, recognizing achievement in American theatre, were handed out at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City.
The first of the 1979 Nepalese student protests broke out, which forced the monarchy to concede to holding a referendum on the possibility of a multiparty system in the country.
Egyptian workers staged an illegal general strike, two days before key municipal elections.
Dutch sailor Jan van Riebeeck landed at Table Bay in Southern Africa, establishing a settlement that later became known as Cape Town.
A group of 23 slaves in New York City revolted, setting fire to a building, but were soon recaptured.
Napoleonic Wars: British forces captured the French frigate Niémen in the Bay of Biscay.
Peninsular War: After a three-week siege, the Anglo-Portuguese Army, under the Earl of Wellington, captured Badajoz, Spain, and forced the surrender of the French garrison.
Joseph Smith, Oliver Cowdery, David Whitmer and others formally organized the Church of Christ, starting the Latter Day Saint movement.
World War II: German forces invaded Greece.
World War II: The Luftwaffe began Operation Retribution, bombing the Yugoslav capital of Belgrade in retaliation for a coup d'état that overthrew the government that had signed the Tripartite Pact.
Second World War: The Battle of Slater's Knoll on Bougainville Island concluded with a decisive victory for the Australian Army's 7th Brigade against the Imperial Japanese Army's 6th Division.
Four California Highway Patrol officers were killed in a shootout following a traffic stop in Newhall, north of Los Angeles.
Lithuanian president Rolandas Paksas became the first European head of state to be removed from office by impeachment.
Kurdish leader Jalal Talabani was elected by the National Assembly as the first non-Arab president of Iraq.
An earthquake measuring 6.3 Mw struck near L'Aquila in the central Italian region of Abruzzo, killing 308 people and leaving more than 66,000 homeless.
Naxalite–Maoist insurgency: Insurgents from the Communist Party of India (Maoist) ambushed a Central Reserve Police Force convoy in Dantewada district, India, killing 76 officers.
The National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad unilaterally declared the region of Azawad independent from Mali.
American Revolutionary War: Ships of the Continental Navy unsuccessfully attempted to capture HMS Glasgow near Block Island.
John Jacob Astor founded the American Fur Company, the profits from which made him the first multi-millionaire in the United States.
ABBA won the Eurovision Song Contest representing Sweden with the song "Waterloo".
The aircraft carrying Rwandan president Juvénal Habyarimana and Burundian president Cyprien Ntaryamira was shot down in Kigali; the event became the catalyst for the Rwandan genocide.
Mass protests began across Moldova against the results of the parliamentary election.
Byzantine Emperor Justinian I issued the first draft of the Corpus Juris Civilis, a collection of fundamental works in jurisprudence.
The Anarchy: Empress Matilda became the first female claimant to the throne of England, adopting the title "Lady of the English" after failing to be crowned in place of her cousin Stephen.
Charles, King of Bohemia, issued a Golden Bull to establish Charles University in Prague, the first university in Central Europe.
Johann Sebastian Bach premiered his St John Passion, a musical setting of the Passion of Jesus, at Good Friday Vespers in St. Nicholas Church, Leipzig.
Troops of the Burmese Konbaung Dynasty sacked the Siamese city of Ayutthaya to end the Burmese–Siamese War, bringing the four-century-old Ayutthaya Kingdom to an end.
American pioneers established the town of Marietta (now in Ohio), the first permanent American settlement in the Northwest Territory.
German composer Ludwig van Beethoven premiered his Third Symphony, at the Theater an der Wien in Vienna.
Thomas D'Arcy McGee, a Canadian Father of Confederation, was assassinated; to date, the only Canadian political assassination at the federal level.
Educator Booker T. Washington became the first African American to be featured on a U.S. postage stamp.

Cold War: U.S. president Dwight D. Eisenhower introduced the domino theory, speculating that if one nation in a region came under the influence of communism, then its surrounding countries would follow in a domino effect.
Spain relinquished its protectorate in Morocco.
Steve Crocker published RFC 1, the first in a series of Request for Comments documents that helped shape the evolution of the Internet.

Violent protests started in the Kyrgyz capital Bishkek in response to perceived corruption and rising living expenses, eventually resulting in the collapse of President Kurmanbek Bakiyev's government.
American Civil War: Union forces defeated Confederate troops at the Battle of Shiloh, at the time the bloodiest battle in U.S. history, in Hardin County, Tennessee.
An Arctic expedition led by Norwegian explorer Fridtjof Nansen reached 86°13.6′N, almost three degrees beyond the previous Farthest North latitude.
Italian dictator Benito Mussolini survived an assassination attempt by Irishwoman Violet Gibson.
The United Nations established the World Health Organization to act as a coordinating authority on international public health.
The Rodgers and Hammerstein musical South Pacific, based on Tales of the South Pacific by James Michener, opened on Broadway.
American Presbyterian minister Bruce W. Klunder was killed by a bulldozer while protesting the construction of a segregated school in Cleveland, Ohio.
Communist forces overran the South Vietnamese town of Lộc Ninh.
Uganda–Tanzania War: Tanzanian forces defeated Ugandan troops and their Libyan allies at the Battle of Entebbe, opening the way for an advance on the Ugandan capital, Kampala.
A FedEx employee tried to hijack Federal Express Flight 705 in a failed suicide attempt.
A hijacker deliberately drove a truck into crowds along Drottninggatan in Stockholm, Sweden, killing five people.
After a conclave lasting eighty days, the College of Cardinals elected Fabio Chigi as Pope Alexander VII.
World War II: U.S. forces sank the Japanese battleship Yamato during Operation Kikusui I in the East China Sea.
Rwandan Civil War: The Rwandan genocide began a few hours after the assassination of President Juvénal Habyarimana, with hundreds of thousands killed in the following 100 days.
First Chechen War: Russian paramilitary troops began a massacre of hundreds of civilians in Samashki, Chechnya.
NASA's 2001 Mars Odyssey (artist's conception pictured), the longest-surviving continually active spacecraft in orbit around a planet other than Earth, launched from Cape Canaveral.
Winchester Cathedral at Winchester in Hampshire, one of the largest cathedrals in England, was dedicated by Bishop Walkelin.
Seventh Crusade: Egyptian Ayyubid forces defeated the Crusader army at the Battle of Fariskur in Egypt, capturing King Louis IX of France.
Italian scholar and poet Petrarch took the title of poet laureate at a ceremony in Rome.
War of the Austrian Succession: The Royal Navy captured the Spanish ship of the line Princesa, which was later taken into British service.
Gallaudet University, the world's only university for hearing-impaired students, was established in Washington, D.C.
British prime minister William Ewart Gladstone introduced the Government of Ireland Bill in the House of Commons.
British occultist and writer Aleister Crowley began transcribing The Book of the Law, one of the Holy Books of Thelema.
Dutch physicist Heike Kamerlingh Onnes discovered superconductivity.
American tennis player Arthur Ashe announced that he had contracted HIV from blood transfusions; he spent the remainder of his life as an AIDS activist.
The wind turbines at the Bahrain World Trade Center, the first building to incorporate turbines into its design, became operational.
On board Soyuz TMA-12, Yi So-yeon became the first Korean astronaut.
The Islamic State of Iraq and the Al-Nusra Front, two Sunni Muslim extremist groups, merged to form the Islamic State.
Roman emperor Caracalla was assassinated near Harran and succeeded by his Praetorian Guard prefect Macrinus.
Abbasid forces decisively defeated the Saffarid emir Ya'qub ibn Laith, forcing the latter to halt his advance into Iraq.
Kiliaen van Rensselaer purchased land near present-day Albany, New York, to establish Rensselaerswyck, which became the most successful patroonship under the Dutch West India Company.
The Venus de Milo, an ancient Greek statue of a woman with its arms missing, was discovered on the island of Milos.
American Civil War: Late-arriving reinforcements helped Confederate forces rout the Union Army at the Battle of Mansfield.
Longacre Square in Midtown Manhattan was renamed Times Square after the New York Times building.
World War I: German naval officer Wilhelm Werner murdered 19 captured crew members of the British cargo ship Torrington by submerging U-55 when they were on deck.
A team of computer scientists and others met to discuss the creation of a common business-oriented programming language, which became COBOL.
World War II: The United States Army Air Forces flew its first mission from India over the Hump (the eastern end of the Himalayas) to deliver materiel to China.
Otto and Elise Hampel were executed in Berlin for performing acts of resistance against Nazism.
A large explosion on board the MV Dara in the Persian Gulf killed 238 people.

BOAC Flight 712 experienced an engine fire shortly after take-off from London Heathrow, leading to the deaths of five people on board, including flight attendant Jane Harrison, who was posthumously awarded a George Cross for heroism.
Crusades: The Knights Hospitaller surrendered the Krak des Chevaliers, a castle in present-day Syria, to the army of the Mamluk sultan Baybars.
France and the United Kingdom signed the Entente Cordiale, agreeing to a peaceful coexistence after centuries of intermittent conflict.
American cartoonist Winsor McCay released the silent short film Little Nemo (featured), one of the earliest animated films.
The Australian state of Western Australia voted to secede from the federation, but efforts to implement the result proved to be unsuccessful.
The Progress Party was founded in a movie theater in Oslo, Norway.
A combined force of Poles and Germans attempted to halt the Mongol invasion of Europe at the Battle of Legnica near present-day Legnica, Poland.
Henry V, later featured in three plays by William Shakespeare, was crowned King of England.
Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville recorded himself singing "Au clair de la lune" on his phonautograph, producing the oldest known recording of an audible human voice.
Confederate forces under Robert E. Lee surrendered to Ulysses S. Grant at the McLean House near the Appomattox Court House in Virginia, effectively ending the American Civil War.
The Civil Rights Act, the first United States federal legislation to affirm that all citizens are equally protected by law, was enacted.

World War I: Aníbal Milhais's actions at the Battle of the Lys made him the only person to be awarded Portugal's highest military honour, the Order of the Tower and Sword, directly on the battlefield.
World War II: Nazi Germany began Operation Weserübung, invading Denmark and Norway.

World War II: Japanese forces defeated Allied troops at the Battle of Bataan in the Philippines before beginning to forcibly transfer more than 90,000 prisoners of war to prison camps in the Bataan Death March.
An anti-Soviet demonstration in Tbilisi, Georgia, was quashed by the Red Army, resulting in 20 deaths and hundreds of injuries.
First World War: The Canadian Corps began the first wave of attacks of the Battle of Vimy Ridge in Vimy, France.

After being denied permission to perform at Constitution Hall by the Daughters of the American Revolution, African-American singer Marian Anderson gave an open-air concert on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C.
World War II: During the German invasion of Norway, Vidkun Quisling attempted to seize power in the first coup to be broadcast over radio.
Sixteen white and black men began a two-week journey in the American South, acting in defiance of local laws that enforced segregated seating on public buses.
The Glazier–Higgins–Woodward tornadoes killed 181 people and injured 970 others in Texas, Oklahoma, and Kansas.
Palestine war: Fighters from the Zionist paramilitary groups Irgun and Lehi attacked the village of Deir Yassin near Jerusalem, killing more than 100 Palestinian Arabs.
NASA announced the selection of the Mercury Seven, the first astronauts in Project Mercury.
The Boeing 737 took its maiden flight, eventually becoming the most produced commercial passenger jet airliner in the world.
The first EMD F40PH, Amtrak's most widespread diesel locomotive for many years, entered into service.
Iraqi philosopher Muhammad Baqir al-Sadr and his sister Amina were executed by the regime of Saddam Hussein.
Iranian filmmaker Morteza Avini was killed by a land mine in Fakkeh while producing a documentary.
Ibrahim Baré Maïnassara, President of Niger, was shot dead by soldiers in Niamey.
Invasion of Iraq: Coalition forces captured Baghdad and the statue of Saddam Hussein in Firdos Square was toppled.
Prince Philip, the consort of Queen Elizabeth II, died at Windsor Castle aged 99.
Year of the Five Emperors: Septimius Severus was proclaimed Roman emperor by his troops at Carnuntum in modern-day Austria.
Despite being vastly outnumbered, forces of the Old Swiss Confederacy defeated an Austrian army at the Battle of Näfels.
The German heavy cruiser Admiral Scheer, the most successful capital-ship surface raider of the Second World War, was sunk by British bombers in port in Kiel.
Charles, Prince of Wales, married Camilla Parker Bowles in a civil ceremony at the Windsor Guildhall.
Myanmar civil war: Burmese military and police forces killed at least 82 civilians in the Bago massacre, including people protesting a recent coup d'état.
President James Madison signed the charter establishing the Second Bank of the United States as the nation's second national bank.
A British military expedition to Abyssinia culminated in a rout of the Ethiopian Empire and the later suicide of Emperor Tewodros II.
Crown Prince Akihito, the future Emperor of Japan, wedded Michiko, the first commoner to marry into the Japanese Imperial Family.
In the best-known maritime disaster in New Zealand's history, the inter-island ferry TEV Wahine capsized outside Wellington harbour, killing 53 of the 733 people on board.
In an attempt to thaw Sino-American relations, members of the American table tennis team entered the People's Republic of China for a weeklong visit.
Ireland and the United Kingdom signed the Good Friday Agreement, a major step in the Northern Ireland peace process.

Fijian President Ratu Josefa Iloilo announced that he had suspended the constitution and assumed all governance in the country after it was ruled that the government of Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama was illegal.
A Tupolev Tu-154M aircraft carrying President Lech Kaczyński and other Polish officials crashed while attempting to land in heavy fog at Smolensk-North air base, Russia, killing all 96 on board.
Greek War of Independence: Inhabitants of the Greek town of Missolonghi attempted to escape a year-long siege, but were caught and killed by Ottoman forces.
A Mongol army commanded by Tolui captured the city of Merv in present-day Turkmenistan, allegedly killing more than 1.7 million people.

War of the Austrian Succession: Prussian forces defeated Austrian troops at the Battle of Mollwitz in present-day Małujowice, Poland, cementing Frederick II's authority over the newly conquered territory of Silesia.
Big Ben, the bell in the Palace of Westminster's clock tower in London, was cast after the original bell cracked during testing.
Mexican Revolution leader Emiliano Zapata was shot to death near Ciudad Ayala, Morelos.

The Holocaust: Slovak Jewish prisoners Rudolf Vrba and Alfréd Wetzler escaped from Auschwitz, later publishing a report that became one of the earliest and most detailed descriptions of the camp's mass killings.
The U.S. Navy nuclear submarine USS Thresher (SSN-593) sank with all hands lost during deep-diving tests in the North Atlantic Ocean.
In the deadliest aviation accident in Swiss history, Invicta International Airlines Flight 435 crashed into a hillside near Hochwald, killing 108 people of 145 on board.
First Nagorno-Karabakh War: Dozens of Armenian civilians were massacred in the village of Maraga by Azerbaijani forces.
Napoleonic Wars: The War of the Fifth Coalition began with the Austrian invasion of Bavaria, then a client state of France.
Mount Tambora in Indonesia began the most powerful volcanic eruption in recorded history, killing at least 71,000 people and affecting temperatures worldwide.
The Great Gatsby (cover pictured), a novel by American author F. Scott Fitzgerald, was first published by Scribner's.
In the midst of business disagreements with his bandmates, Paul McCartney announced his departure from the Beatles.
Scientists from the Event Horizon Telescope project released the first image of the black hole at the center of the galaxy M87.
Bahía Blanca in Argentina was founded as a fortress to protect dwellers and their cattle from native rustling, and to protect the coast from the Brazilian Navy.
The city of Tel Aviv in Ottoman Syria was founded as 66 Jewish families held a lottery to distribute land their organisation had purchased north of Jaffa.
World War II: American forces liberated the Buchenwald concentration camp near Weimar, Germany.
Air India's Kashmir Princess was destroyed in mid-air by a bomb in an assassination attempt on Chinese Premier Zhou Enlai, who had not been on board.
Almost 50 confirmed tornadoes struck six states in the Midwestern United States during the Palm Sunday tornado outbreak, killing over 270 people and injuring 1,500 others.
U.S. president Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act of 1968, prohibiting racial discrimination in the sale, rental, and financing of housing.

Tensions between residents and the police in Brixton, South London, escalated into a massive riot that resulted in almost 300 police injuries, 45 civilian injuries, over a hundred vehicles burned, and over 150 buildings damaged.
Eight FBI agents exchanged gunfire with two bank robbers in Miami, Florida, which led to the introduction of more powerful handguns in many police departments around the country.
Mongol invasion of Europe: Mongol forces led by Batu Khan and Subutai defeated the army of King Béla IV at the Battle of Mohi near the river Sajó, a key victory in their first invasion of Hungary.
Italian War of 1542–1546: French and Spanish forces fought a massive pitched battle in the Piedmont region of Italy.
The main treaties of the Peace of Utrecht were signed in Utrecht in the Dutch Republic, helping to end the War of the Spanish Succession.
The Treaty of Fontainebleau was signed, ending the War of the Sixth Coalition and forcing Napoleon to abdicate as ruler of France and sending him into exile on Elba.
The Concertgebouw in Amsterdam, considered one of the world's finest concert halls, was inaugurated.
Blücher, the last armored cruiser built by the Imperial German Navy, was launched.

The cricket pavilion at the Nevill Ground was destroyed in an arson attack (damage pictured) that was attributed to militant suffragettes as part of a country-wide campaign co-ordinated by the Women's Social and Political Union.
Paris Peace Conference: Woodrow Wilson overturns Japan's Racial Equality Proposal, stating that unanimous support was required.
Emir Abdullah established the first centralised government in the recently created British protectorate of Transjordan.
Pope John XXIII issued Pacem in terris, the first papal encyclical addressed to "all men of good will" rather than only to Catholics.
Rudi Dutschke, the most prominent leader of the German student movement, survived an assassination attempt, which led to the largest protests to that date in Germany.
On the Art of the Cinema, a treatise on film propaganda in support of the ruling Workers' Party of Korea written by the future North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, was published.
Uganda–Tanzania War: The allied forces of Tanzania and the Uganda National Liberation Front captured the capital Kampala, deposing Ugandan president Idi Amin.
Prisoners at the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility near Lucasville, Ohio, rioted and took over the prison for 11 days, resulting in the deaths of one officer and nine inmates.

While attempting to set a record as the youngest person to pilot an airplane across the United States, the aircraft flown by seven-year-old Jessica Dubroff crashed in Cheyenne, Wyoming, killing her and two others.
In a coup attempt, members of the Venezuelan military detained President Hugo Chávez and demanded his resignation.
A bomb exploded at the central Oktyabrskaya station of the Minsk Metro in Belarus, killing 15 people and injuring more than 200.
The tour bus of the German football team Borussia Dortmund was attacked with roadside bombs in Dortmund, killing a police officer and injuring one of the team's players.
A Myanmar Air Force airstrike killed at least 100 villagers in Pazigyi.
William III and Mary II (both pictured) were crowned joint sovereigns of England in a ceremony at Westminster Abbey.
Napoleonic Wars: A hastily assembled Royal Navy fleet launched an assault against the main strength of the French Atlantic Fleet; an incomplete victory led to political turmoil in Britain.
U.S. president Harry S. Truman relieved General of the Army Douglas MacArthur of his commands for making public statements about the Korean War that contradicted the administration's policies.
In a FIFA World Cup qualifying match, Australia defeated American Samoa 31–0, the largest margin of victory recorded in international football.
Shapur I was crowned the shahanshah ('king of kings') of the Sasanian Empire, the last Iranian empire before the rise of Islam.
Anthemius was proclaimed Western Roman Emperor at the third or twelfth mile from Rome.
A royal decree established the Union Jack to symbolise the Union of the Crowns, merging the designs of the flag of England and the flag of Scotland.
American Revolutionary War: The Royal Navy defeated a French fleet at the Battle of the Saintes, forcing the latter to abandon a planned invasion of Jamaica.
Chinese Civil War: A large-scale purge of Chinese communists from the nationalist Kuomintang began in Shanghai.
Columbia, the first spaceworthy space shuttle, was launched from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on its first flight.

Jim Gary became the only sculptor to present a solo show at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History in Washington, D.C., featuring his trademark dinosaur sculptures made of automobile parts.
Disneyland Paris, the first Walt Disney park in Europe, opened in the Paris suburb of Marne-la-Vallée.
Husband-and-wife law partners Laurence Canter and Martha Siegel posted the first massive commercial spam on Usenet.
The canteen of the Council of Representatives of Iraq building was attacked by a suicide bomber, killing one Member of Parliament and wounding 23 other people.
American Revolution: The North Carolina Provincial Congress passed the Halifax Resolves, the first official action in the American colonies calling for independence from Great Britain.
The Froberg mutiny of Greek and Albanian troops in British service ended with the explosion of the gunpowder magazine at Fort Ricasoli, Malta.
Greek War of Independence: Ottoman troops began a massacre of tens of thousands of Greeks (depicted) on the island of Chios.
The Broughton Suspension Bridge near Manchester, England, collapsed reportedly because of mechanical resonance induced by troops marching in step across it.
Confederate forces began a bombardment of Fort Sumter in the harbor of Charleston, South Carolina, starting the American Civil War.
Aboard Vostok 1, Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin performed the first human spaceflight, completing one orbit of Earth in 108 minutes.
About 1,700 gravediggers in New York City began a 12-week strike, causing a delay in the burial of roughly 1,400 bodies in the city.
Canadian athlete Terry Fox embarked on an east-to-west "Marathon of Hope" from St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, with a prosthetic leg to raise funds for cancer research.
Harold Washington was elected as the first African-American mayor of Chicago.
Bosnian War: NATO forces began Operation Deny Flight (aircraft pictured) to enforce a no-fly zone over Bosnia and Herzegovina ordered by the United Nations Security Council.
The Guinea-Bissau military seized control in a coup amid a presidential election, later handing power to a transitional administration under Manuel Serifo Nhamadjo.
Four Chadian soldiers were killed in a suicide bombing by jihadist rebels in Kidal, Mali.
King Edwin of Northumbria was baptised by Bishop Paulinus of York.
Troops of the Fourth Crusade entered Constantinople and began a sack of the city, temporarily dissolving the Byzantine Empire.
SMS Zrínyi, one of the last pre-dreadnoughts built by the Austro-Hungarian Navy, was launched in Trieste.
Samuel Doe took control of Liberia in a coup d'état, overthrowing President William Tolbert and ending over 130 years of national democratic presidential succession.
A fire broke out near Valparaíso, Chile, eventually destroying at least 2,500 homes and leaving approximately 11,000 people homeless (damage pictured).
Henry V, the last ruler of the Salian dynasty, was crowned Holy Roman Emperor.

In the wake of a disputed election for local offices in Colfax, Louisiana, armed white supremacists overpowered freedmen and the African-American state militia trying to control the parish courthouse, killing over 100 of them.
The Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea, a government in exile based in Shanghai during the Japanese occupation of Korea, was formed.
British Indian Army troops massacred hundreds of unarmed men, women and children who were attending a peaceful gathering at the Jallianwala Bagh in Amritsar.
The Soviet Union and Japan signed a neutrality pact that lasted through most of World War II.

World War II: German news announced the discovery of a mass grave of Polish prisoners of war killed by Soviet forces in Katyn, Russia, causing a diplomatic rift between the Polish government-in-exile and the Soviet Union.
World War II: Soviet and Bulgarian forces captured Vienna in Austria.
Civil war in Mandatory Palestine: A convoy bringing supplies and personnel to Jerusalem's Hadassah Hospital was ambushed by Arab forces, leaving 79 people dead.
Kashmir conflict: Indian forces launched a pre-emptive attack on the disputed Siachen Glacier in Kashmir, triggering a military conflict with Pakistan.
Czech politician Vít Jedlička proclaimed the creation of the micronation Liberland on a patch of land between Croatia and Serbia that had been unclaimed by either side due to a territorial dispute.
The first performance of George Frideric Handel's celebrated oratorio Messiah took place in Dublin.
During a closed session of the Diet of Hungary, Lajos Kossuth presented the Hungarian Declaration of Independence from the Habsburg monarchy.
Austrian soldier Anton Schmid was executed for rescuing Jews from the Ponary massacre in Vilnius.
The Neoclassical Jefferson Memorial in Washington, D.C., was formally dedicated on the 200th anniversary of Thomas Jefferson's birth.
Nakam, a Jewish organization seeking revenge for the Holocaust, attempted to poison thousands of SS prisoners at Langwasser internment camp, but did not kill anyone.
Ian Fleming's novel Casino Royale was published as the first work to feature the British spy character James Bond.
The CIA began Project MKUltra, an illegal, covert human research program into mind control.
The Vietnamese National Army captured Ba Cụt, a military commander of the religious sect Hòa Hảo, which ran a de facto state in South Vietnam in opposition to Prime Minister Ngô Đình Diệm.
Catch a Fire, the landmark reggae album by Bob Marley and the Wailers, was released.
Forty people died in an explosion at an ammunition factory in Lapua, Finland.
In golf, 21-year-old Tiger Woods became the youngest player to win the Masters Tournament, breaking the record for the lowest four-round score.
Twenty-three people died in a fire at a homeless hostel in Kamień Pomorski; it was Poland's deadliest fire since 1980.
American Revolutionary War: British and Hessian forces conducted a surprise attack against a Continental Army outpost at Bound Brook, New Jersey.
The Roman Catholic Relief Act received royal assent, removing the most substantial restrictions on Catholics in the United Kingdom.
In the midst of the Cold War, American pianist Van Cliburn won the inaugural International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow.
Andrew Hussie's webcomic Homestuck debuted, and concluded on the same day in 2016.
War in Afghanistan: In an airstrike in Nangarhar Province, the U.S. military dropped the most powerful conventional bomb used in combat.
The foundation stone of the Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul in Nantes, Brittany, France, was first laid, but the building was not completed until more than four centuries later in 1891.
A mass sighting of celestial phenomena (depicted) occurred in Nuremberg, Germany, where observers described an "aerial battle" between odd-shaped objects.
The first Volvo automobile was built in the factory in Hisingen, Gothenburg, Sweden.
After King Alfonso XIII left Spain, the Second Spanish Republic was proclaimed by a provisional government led by Niceto Alcalá-Zamora.
The Grapes of Wrath, John Steinbeck's Pulitzer Prize–winning novel and a major factor in his 1962 Nobel Prize award, was first published.
The use of 2-inch quadruplex, the first practical and commercially successful videotape format, was first demonstrated in public.
The completion of the Human Genome Project was announced.

In Ankara, Turkey, the first of the Republic Protests took place, when hundreds of thousands of people protested against the possible presidential candidacy of incumbent prime minister Recep Tayyip Erdoğan.
Polish ruler Mieszko I converted to Christianity, an event considered to be the founding of the Polish state.
