The United Nations declared that the world's population had exceeded seven billion.
Shortly after takeoff, Metrojet Flight 9268 (aircraft pictured) exploded and then crashed into the Sinai Peninsula, killing all 224 people on board.
World War I: Allied forces defeated Turkish troops in Beersheba in Southern Palestine at the Battle of Beersheba, with the battle involving one of the last successful cavalry charges.
100 crew members of the USS Reuben James perished when their vessel became the first U.S. Navy ship sunk by hostile action during World War II after it was torpedoed by the German submarine U-552.

A gas explosion at the 
Indiana State Fairgrounds Coliseum in Indianapolis killed 81 people and injured about 400 others.
Three Provisional Irish Republican Army members escaped from Mountjoy Prison in Dublin aboard a hijacked helicopter that landed in the prison's exercise yard.
TG4, the world's first Irish language television station, began broadcasting.
After 22 years in power, Mahathir Mohamad retired as Prime Minister of Malaysia.
Public-transportation workers in Indianapolis went on strike, shutting down mass transit in the city.
Approximately 400 workers completed the 60-foot (18 m) busts of U.S. presidents George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Abraham Lincoln at Mount Rushmore in South Dakota.
Indian prime minister Indira Gandhi was assassinated by two of her own Sikh bodyguards, sparking riots that killed thousands of Sikhs.
All 217 people on board EgyptAir Flight 990 perished when the aircraft suddenly crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Nantucket, Massachusetts.
The discovery of the Plutonian moons Nix and Hydra, based on photographs taken by the Hubble Space Telescope nearly five months prior, was announced.
Romulus Augustulus took the throne as the last emperor of the Western Roman Empire.
Martin Luther posted his Ninety-five Theses onto the door of All Saints' Church in Wittenberg, marking the beginning of the Protestant Reformation.
Australian sailor Jesse Martin arrived in Melbourne, becoming the youngest person to circumnavigate the globe solo, non-stop, and unassisted.
Singapore Airlines Flight 006 collided with construction equipment while attempting to take off from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taiwan during heavy rain, killing 83 people aboard.
An Uzbek immigrant drove a rented truck into cyclists and runners in Lower Manhattan, New York City, killing eight people.
Otto III, Holy Roman Emperor issued a document containing the earliest known use of "Osterrîchi", the Old High German name of Austria.
Giuliano della Rovere was elected pope, taking the name Julius II in emulation of Julius Caesar.
Portuguese maritime explorer Ferdinand Magellan led the first European expedition to navigate the Strait of Magellan.
The first recorded performance of Shakespeare's play The Tempest was held at the Palace of Whitehall in London.
A 9.0 Mw earthquake and subsequent tsunami devastated Lisbon, an event which led to the birth of modern seismology and earthquake engineering.
Reflections on the Revolution in France by Anglo-Irish statesman and philosopher Edmund Burke, was first published, in which he predicted that the French Revolution would end in a disaster.
John Adams became the first U.S. president to take residence in the Executive Mansion, later renamed the White House.
The Colony of New Zealand dissolved its nine provinces and replaced them with 63 counties.
The Gaelic Athletic Association was founded in County Tipperary.
Juventus, Italy's most successful football club, was founded as an athletics club.
The current 29-letter Turkish alphabet was introduced, replacing the Ottoman Turkish alphabet as the official writing system of the Turkish language.
The first game of the National Basketball Association (NBA) took place at Maple Leaf Gardens in Toronto, Canada.
Athenagoras I was elected as the 268th Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople.
Two Puerto Rican nationalists attempted to assassinate U.S. president Harry S. Truman.
The Front de Libération Nationale began the Algerian War of Independence against French rule.
The Mackinac Bridge, the third-longest suspension bridge in total suspension, opened between Upper and Lower peninsulas of the U.S. state of Michigan.
The Arecibo Observatory, with the world's largest single-dish radio telescope, officially opened in Arecibo, Puerto Rico.
The voluntary Motion Picture Association film rating system came into effect for films released in the United States.
The European Court of Human Rights was instituted as a permanent court with full-time judges to monitor compliance by the signatory parties of the European Convention on Human Rights.
Byzantine–Seljuk wars: Seljuq Turks captured the important port city of Sinope.
Frances Kyle was called to the Bar of Ireland, becoming the first female barrister in Ireland or Great Britain.
American photographer Ansel Adams shot Moonrise, Hernandez, New Mexico, one of his most famous photographs.
World War II: An American F-13 Superfortress made the first flight by an Allied aircraft over Tokyo since the Doolittle Raid in April 1942.
After being struck in the face with a hockey puck, Jacques Plante played the rest of the game wearing a face mask, now mandatory equipment for goaltenders in ice hockey.
Dominique Mbonyumutwa, one of the few Hutu sub-chiefs in colonial Rwanda, was attacked by Tutsi activists, precipitating the Rwandan Revolution.
Lê Quang Tung, loyalist head of the South Vietnam Special Forces, was executed in a U.S.-backed coup against president Ngô Đình Diệm following a period of religious unrest.
After Empress Matilda released her rival King Stephen, he in turn released Robert of Gloucester, her strongest supporter, thus prolonging the Anglo-Norman civil war known as The Anarchy.
The disposable ship Columbus arrived in the The Downs off England, becoming, at that time, the largest vessel to have crossed the Atlantic Ocean.
World War I: The first contingent of the First Australian Imperial Force departed Albany, Western Australia.
The Indian states Kerala, Andhra Pradesh, and Karnataka were formally created under the States Reorganisation Act.
Elvis on Tour, a concert film that documented Elvis Presley's tour throughout the United States, opened.

French Revolution: Under the terms of a new constitution that was ratified during the aftermath of the Reign of Terror and the subsequent Thermidorian Reaction, the Directory succeeded the National Convention as the new executive government.
The Dakota Territory, an organized incorporated territory of the United States, was split and became the states of North and South Dakota.
Organized cheerleading was born at the University of Minnesota when student Johnny Campbell directed a crowd attending an American college football game to cheer on their team.
The BBC Television Service launched as the world's first regular, public all-electronic "high-definition" television service.
Industrialist and aviator Howard Hughes flew the "Spruce Goose", the largest flying boat ever built, on its maiden flight from the coast of Long Beach, California.
The M1 motorway, the first inter-urban motorway to be completed in the United Kingdom, opened between Watford and Crick/Rugby.
American intellectual Charles Van Doren caused a national scandal when he admitted that he had foreknowledge of the questions and answers when he appeared on the television quiz show Twenty-One.
In the trial R v Penguin Books Ltd, publisher Penguin Books was acquitted of obscenity for the publication of Lady Chatterley's Lover by D. H. Lawrence.
King Saud of Saudi Arabia was deposed by his half-brother Faisal over concerns of the former's profligacy and his inability to deal with the socialism of Egypt's Gamal Abdel Nasser.
American Quaker Norman Morrison set himself on fire in front of the Pentagon to protest the United States' involvement in the Vietnam War.
The Morris worm, the first computer worm distributed via the Internet to gain significant mainstream media attention, was launched by university student Robert Tappan Morris.
Sky Television and British Satellite Broadcasting merged to form BSkyB, currently the largest pay-TV broadcaster in Europe.
Former South African minister of defence Magnus Malan and 19 others were arrested and charged with 13 murders in the KwaMakhutha massacre of 1987, for which they were all acquitted.
Dutch film director Theo van Gogh, whose film Submission was critical of the treatment of women in Islam, was assassinated by Mohammed Bouyeri.
The Chicago Cubs defeated the Cleveland Indians in the 2016 World Series, ending the longest championship drought in Major League Baseball history.
Emperor Gaozu of Tang allowed the assassination of a khagan of the Western Turkic Khaganate by Eastern Turkic rivals, one of the earliest events in the Tang campaigns against the Western Turks.
The British government issued the Balfour Declaration in support of a Jewish homeland in Palestine, then an Ottoman region with a small Jewish minority.
World War II: A U.S. Navy task force turned away an Imperial Japanese Navy formation at the Battle of Empress Augusta Bay, thus protecting the landings at Cape Torokina.
A large number of people witnessed a fiery object in the sky near Levelland, Texas, which the United States Air Force said was ball lightning.
President Ngô Đình Diệm of South Vietnam was assassinated, marking the culmination of a coup d'état led by Dương Văn Minh.
The serial killer Velma Barfield became the first woman to be executed in the United States since 1962.
Tropical Storm Linda made landfall in the Mekong Delta in Vietnam, causing more than 3,000 deaths.
Lewis Hamilton overtook Timo Glock in the final corners of the Brazilian Grand Prix to win the Formula One championship by one point.
James A. Garfield was elected as president of the United States; the election is the closest to date by popular vote margin.
The Australian military began a "war against emus", flightless native birds blamed for widespread damage to crops in Western Australia.
The Dutch–Indonesian Round Table Conference ended with the Netherlands agreeing to transfer sovereignty of the Dutch East Indies to the United States of Indonesia.
A lightning strike ruptured three oil tanks near Dronka, Egypt, causing a flood that killed 469 people.

As members of Expedition 1, American astronaut William Shepherd and Russian cosmonauts Sergei Krikalev and Yuri Gidzenko (all pictured) became the first resident crew to arrive at the International Space Station.
Umar, the second Caliph in Sunni Islam after Muhammad's death, was fatally stabbed by Piruz Nahavandi, a Persian slave.
The Times of India, the world's highest-circulation English-language daily broadsheet newspaper, was founded as the The Bombay Times and Journal of Commerce.
The Coimbra Academic Association, Portugal's oldest students' union, was founded at the University of Coimbra.
The German Revolution began when 40,000 sailors took over the port of Kiel.
Vietnam War: A series of major engagements that were some of the hardest-fought and bloodiest battles of the war began at Đắk Tô in the Central Highlands.
The Unix Programmer's Manual was first published.
Five members of the U.S. Communist Workers' Party were shot and killed by members of the Ku Klux Klan and the American Nazi Party while in a protest in Greensboro, North Carolina.
The Peruvian paramilitary death squad Grupo Colina massacred at least fifteen people in the Barrios Altos neighborhood of Lima.
Pakistani president and chief of army staff Pervez Musharraf declared a state of emergency across Pakistan, suspending the Pakistani Constitution.
The Parliament of England passed the first Act of Supremacy, making King Henry VIII head of the Church of England, supplanting the pope and the Catholic Church.
French Revolution: Playwright, journalist and outspoken feminist Olympe de Gouges  was guillotined.
War of the Third Coalition: The Treaty of Potsdam was signed compelling Prussia to join the coalition if it failed to negotiate peace between Russia and France.
A new constitution drafted by Johan Rudolph Thorbecke was proclaimed, limiting the powers of the Dutch monarchy.
The current melody of Kimigayo, the national anthem of Japan, was adopted.
The Fashoda Incident ended with French forces withdrawing after several months of military stalemate with the British in Fashoda (now in South Sudan).
In a widely criticised referendum, almost 98 percent of Greek voters supported the restoration of George II as King of the Hellenes.
World War II: U.S. Marines and U.S. Army forces began an attempt to encircle and destroy a regiment of Imperial Japanese Army troops on Guadalcanal.

The Chicago Daily Tribune published the erroneous headline "Dewey Defeats Truman" in its early morning edition shortly after incumbent U.S. president Harry S. Truman officially upset the heavily favored governor of New York Thomas Dewey in the presidential election.
Suez Crisis: During an invasion of the Gaza Strip, Israeli soldiers shot and killed hundreds of Palestinian refugees and local inhabitants in Khan Yunis.
The Soviet Union launched Sputnik 2, carrying the space dog Laika as the first living creature to enter orbit around Earth.
U.S. president Richard Nixon made a plea for support from the "silent majority", referring to those Americans who did not join in the large demonstrations against the Vietnam War at the time.
French invasion of Russia: As Napoleon's Grande Armée began its retreat, its rear guard was defeated at the Battle of Vyazma.
Indigenous Mapuche began an uprising against the occupation of Araucanía by Chile.
The Holocaust: The largest massacre of Jews by German forces began at Majdanek concentration camp.
The first film featuring the giant monster known as Godzilla was released (poster pictured) nationwide in Japan.
Abdullah Çatlı, a leader of the ultra-nationalist Grey Wolves, was killed in a car crash near Susurluk, Turkey, sparking a scandal that exposed the depth of the state's complicity in organized crime.
The Teatro di San Carlo in Naples, Italy, currently the oldest active opera house in Europe, was inaugurated.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's Symphony No. 36 was performed for the first time in Linz, Austria.

Northwest Indian War: In the most severe defeat ever suffered by U.S. forces at the hands of Native Americans, the Western Confederacy won a major victory at the Battle of the Wabash near present-day Fort Recovery in Ohio.
Scottish physician James Young Simpson discovered the anaesthetic qualities of chloroform on humans.
Count Cavour became Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Piedmont-Sardinia, which soon expanded to become the Kingdom of Italy.
Nature, one of the oldest and most reputable general-purpose scientific journals, was first published.
Menelik II, who would later introduce several technological and administrative advances under his reign, was crowned Emperor of Ethiopia.

After a speech by Adolf Hitler in the Hofbräuhaus in Munich, members of the Sturmabteilung, known as "brownshirts", physically assaulted his opposition, an event which assumed legendary proportions over time.

At the Kasakela chimpanzee community in Tanzania, Jane Goodall observed a chimpanzee using a grass stalk to extract termites from a termite hill, the first recorded case of tool creation by non-human animals.
The Arno River flooded Florence, Italy, to a maximum depth of 6.7 m (22 ft), leaving thousands homeless and damaging or destroying millions of books and paintings.
Salvador Allende took office as President of Chile, the first Marxist to become president of a Latin American country through open elections.
Hundreds of Iranian students supporting the Iranian Revolution seized the U.S. embassy in Tehran, beginning a 444-day hostage crisis.
Former Philippine First Lady Imelda Marcos was granted a presidential pardon by Corazon Aquino and allowed to return from exile.
American Civil War: Nathan Bedford Forrest led a cavalry division in an attack on a Union Army supply base at Johnsonville, Tennessee, resulting in the capture of 150 prisoners.
The City and South London Railway (carriage pictured), the first deep-level underground railway in the world, officially opened, running 3.2 mi (5.1 km) between the City of London and Stockwell.
The keel of USS Nevada was laid down, beginning construction on the United States Navy's first "super-dreadnought".
The remains of an unknown soldier were buried with an eternal flame at the Altare della Patria in Rome.
The tomb of Tutankhamun was discovered by a team led by British Egyptologist Howard Carter.
The Hlinka Guard and Slovakian police began the deportation of several thousand Jews from the country.
Second World War: Allied forces completed Operation Pheasant, a major operation to clear German troops from the province of North Brabant in the Netherlands.
Robert A. Lovett, United States Secretary of Defense, issued a memorandum establishing the National Security Agency, with responsibility for all communications intelligence for the government.
Ruhollah Khomeini was arrested by SAVAK, the Iranian secret police, and exiled to Turkey.
Barack Obama became the first person of biracial or African-American descent to be elected President of the United States.
The Paris Agreement, under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, came into effect.
A UPS Airlines plane crashed in Louisville, Kentucky, killing at least twelve people.
Túpac Amaru II led a rebellion of Aymara, Quechua, and mestizo peasants in protest against the Bourbon Reforms in the Spanish Viceroyalty of Peru.
In a special election in Wyoming, Nellie Tayloe Ross became the first woman to be elected as a governor in the United States.
Authorities in California discovered a 13-year-old feral child, pseudonymously known as Genie, who had spent nearly her entire life in social isolation.
Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated by Yigal Amir, a right-wing extremist, at a peace rally at Kings of Israel Square in Tel Aviv.
In the first aviation incident involving an Airbus A380, Qantas Flight 32 suffered an uncontained engine failure and made an emergency landing at Changi Airport in Singapore with no casualties.

Representatives of the Iroquois Confederacy and the British Empire signed the Treaty of Fort Stanwix, adjusting the boundary line between Iroquois lands and British colonial settlements that was previously established by the Royal Proclamation of 1763.
Greek War of Independence: the last of the Ottoman forces departed the Morea (now known as the Peloponnese) after the French Morea expedition to recapture the peninsula.
The collapse of the Federal Republic of Central America began with Nicaragua seceding from the union.
American Civil War: Abraham Lincoln removed George B. McClellan as commander of the Union Army for the second and final time.
Filipinos on Negros Island revolted against Spanish rule and established the short-lived Republic of Negros.
Otto, King of Bavaria, was deposed by his cousin, Prince Regent Ludwig, who assumed the title Ludwig III.

Emperors Wilhelm II of Germany and Franz Joseph of Austria issued the Act of 5th November, proposing the creation of a Kingdom of Poland, which would actually be a puppet state allied to and controlled by them.
St. Tikhon of Moscow was elected Patriarch of Moscow and of the Russian Orthodox Church.
Sidney Reilly, known as the "Ace of Spies" and an inspiration for James Bond, was executed by the Soviet secret police.
A train derailed near Hither Green maintenance depot in London, killing 49 people and injuring 78 others.
Five workers on the Byford Dolphin semi-submersible oil rig were killed in an explosive decompression while drilling in the Frigg gas field in the North Sea.
Morning Ireland, Ireland's highest-rated radio programme, was broadcast on RTÉ Radio 1 for the first time.
Led by Google, 34 companies established the Open Handset Alliance to develop open standards for mobile devices, leading to the development of the Android operating system.
Lý Anh Tông was enthroned as the emperor of Đại Việt at the age of two, beginning a 37-year reign.
The arrest of Guy Fawkes, found during a search of the Palace of Westminster, foiled the Gunpowder Plot, which planned to blow up the House of Lords.
Seven Years' War: Prussian forces led by Frederick the Great defeated the allied French and Habsburg armies at the Battle of Rossbach.
World War II: An unknown aircraft dropped four bombs on Vatican City, which maintained neutrality during the war.
Korean War: The 27th British Commonwealth Brigade succeeded in preventing a Chinese breakthrough at the Battle of Pakchon.
Aline Chrétien thwarted André Dallaire's attempt to assassinate her husband, Canadian prime minister Jean Chrétien, by locking the bedroom door in 24 Sussex Drive, their official residence in Ottawa.
American serial killer Gary Ridgway pleaded guilty to 48 counts of first-degree murder.
U.S. Army major Nidal Hasan went on a shooting rampage at Fort Hood, Texas, the worst shooting ever to take place on an American military base, killing 13.
The Indian Space Research Organisation launched the Mars Orbiter Mission, India's first interplanetary probe.
At the Second Battle of Panipat, forces of the Mughal emperor Akbar captured Hemu, the Hindu emperor of north India.
Crimean War: Despite being severely outnumbered, and fighting in heavy foggy conditions, the allied armies of the United Kingdom and France defeated the Russians in present-day Inkerman, Ukraine.
An armed confrontation in Everett, Washington, between local authorities and members of the Industrial Workers of the World resulted in seven deaths.
World War II: Allied forces began a military campaign on Japanese-occupied Singapore.
Israeli ultra-nationalist rabbi Meir Kahane was assassinated in a New York City hotel by an Arab gunman.
A powerful earthquake destroyed large portions of the Walls of Constantinople, including 57 towers.
Pope Pius VI appointed Father John Carroll as the first Catholic bishop in the United States.
Abraham Lincoln won the U.S. presidential election, becoming the first Republican Party candidate to do so.

Months after the end of the American Civil War, the CSS Shenandoah became the last Confederate combat unit to surrender after circumnavigating the globe on a cruise on which it sank or captured 38 vessels.
In the first intercollegiate American football game, Rutgers College defeated the College of New Jersey 6–4 in New Brunswick, New Jersey.
Arnold Rothstein, head of the Jewish mob in New York, died two days after being shot for his failure to pay a large gambling debt.
Before the Institute of Radio Engineers in New York, American electrical engineer and inventor Edwin Howard Armstrong presented his study on using frequency modulation for radio broadcasting.
The Hawker Hurricane, the aircraft responsible for 60% of the Royal Air Force's air victories in the Battle of Britain, made its first flight.
The United Nations General Assembly adopted Resolution 1761, condemning South Africa's apartheid policies.
The United States Atomic Energy Commission conducted the largest underground nuclear test in U.S. history, code-named Cannikin, on Amchitka Island in the Aleutians.
Demonstrators in Morocco began the Green March to Spanish Sahara, calling for the "return of the Moroccan Sahara."

In  Bogotá, Colombia, the Palace of Justice siege left 115 people dead, including all the April 19 Movement rebels that took over the Palace of Justice, and 11 Supreme Court justices that had been held hostages.
Attempting to land at Sumburgh Airport in Shetland, Scotland, carrying workers returning from the Brent oilfield, a Boeing 234LR Chinook crashed into the sea, killing 45 people.
Madagascar's Rova of Antananarivo, which served as the royal palace from the 17th to 19th centuries, was destroyed by fire.

Although opinion polls had clearly suggested that the majority of the electorate favoured republicanism, the Australian republic referendum was defeated, keeping the Australian monarch as the country's official head of state.
King Henry III of England issued the Charter of the Forest, re-establishing the rights of access of free men to royal forests.
French Revolutionary Wars: Two British ships were intercepted by a French squadron, leading to the French seizure of HMS Alexander.
American Civil War: A Union brigade defeated a Confederate force at the Battle of Droop Mountain in Pocahontas County, West Virginia.
Red Cloud, a Native American leader of the Oglala Lakota tribe, signed the Treaty of Fort Laramie, ending Red Cloud's War and establishing the Great Sioux Reservation.
First World War: Canadian forces captured Passendale, Belgium, after three months of fighting against the Germans at the Battle of Passchendaele.
The B Reactor at the Hanford Site in the U.S. state of Washington began producing plutonium, with the facility later going on to create more for nearly the entire American nuclear arsenal.
Nguyễn Ngọc Thơ was appointed by the junta of General Dương Văn Minh to head the South Vietnamese government, five days after Minh deposed and assassinated President Ngô Đình Diệm.
The Kelly Barnes Dam in Stephens County, Georgia, collapsed; the resulting flood killed 39 people and caused US$2.8 million in damages.
Two earthquakes occurring 12 minutes apart struck Yunnan near the China–Myanmar border, killing more than 730 people.
Syrian civil war: The Syrian Democratic Forces launched a successful military campaign to isolate and eventually capture Raqqa, the Islamic State's capital.
The first story from the collection Scenes of Clerical Life by the English author George Eliot was submitted for publication.
As part of their plan to eradicate the Polish intellectual elite, the Gestapo arrested 184 professors, students and employees of the Jagiellonian University (location pictured) in Kraków.
A man committing suicide parked his car on the railway tracks in Ufton Nervet, Berkshire, England, causing a derailment that also killed six people on the train.
Tammy Baldwin became the first openly gay politician to be elected to the United States Senate.
Elizabeth Stuart, a direct ancestor of Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom, was crowned  Queen of Bohemia.
The London Gazette, the oldest surviving English-language newspaper, was first published as the Oxford Gazette.
Lord Dunmore, the royal governor of the Colony of Virginia, signed a proclamation promising freedom for the slaves of Patriots if they joined the British Armed Forces.
Construction of the Canadian Pacific Railway, the first transcontinental railroad across Canada, concluded with the driving of the "last spike" in Craigellachie, British Columbia (ceremony pictured).
Vladimir Lenin led a Bolshevik insurrection against the Provisional Government of Alexander Kerensky, starting the Bolshevik Revolution.
New York City's Museum of Modern Art, often identified as the most influential museum of modern art in the world, opened to the public.
Four months after the bridge's completion, the middle section of the Tacoma Narrows Bridge across the Tacoma Narrows in the U.S. state of Washington collapsed in a windstorm.
World War II: German aircraft sank the Soviet hospital ship Armenia while she was evacuating civilians and wounded soldiers from Crimea, killing an estimated 5,000 people.
Richard Sorge, one of the best-known Soviet intelligence officers of World War II, was hanged in Sugamo Prison, Tokyo, for espionage.
Mary Robinson was elected president of Ireland, the first woman and the first non-Fianna Fáil candidate in the history of contested Irish presidential elections to do so.
A Finnish high school student shot and killed eight people at Jokela High School in Tuusula before committing suicide.
O Ewigkeit, du Donnerwort, BWV 60, a dialogue cantata by Johann Sebastian Bach for Leipzig, was first performed.

Tecumseh's War: American forces led by William Henry Harrison defeated the forces of Shawnee leader Tecumseh's growing confederation at the Battle of Tippecanoe near present-day Battle Ground, Indiana.
American abolitionist Elijah Parish Lovejoy was murdered by a pro-slavery mob in Alton, Illinois, during an attack to destroy his printing press and abolitionist materials.
American Civil War: Future U.S. president Ulysses S. Grant engaged in his first combat leadership role in the Battle of Belmont in Mississippi County, Missouri.
In the congressional elections, Jeannette Rankin became the first woman elected to the United States House of Representatives.
The first specimens of the tufted jay to be scientifically described were collected in Mexico.
Oil was discovered in the Caspian Sea off the coast of Azerbaijan, leading to the construction of Neft Daşları, the world's first offshore oil platform.
Singapore's first Mass Rapid Transit line opened, with train services running between Yio Chu Kang and Toa Payoh.
Magic Johnson announced his retirement from professional basketball due to HIV infection.
NASA launched the Mars Global Surveyor from the Kennedy Space Center at Cape Canaveral, Florida.
Hillary Clinton was elected as a US senator from New York, the first time a first lady had been elected to public office.
The Third Council of Constantinople convened to settle the Christological controversies of monoenergism and monothelitism.
Jereboam O. Beauchamp murdered Kentucky legislator Solomon P. Sharp; Beauchamp later became the first person legally executed in the state.
World War I: British forces captured Gaza following the retreat of the Ottoman garrison.
A ship collision with the Sidney Lanier Bridge in the U.S. state of Georgia resulted in a bridge collapse, which killed ten people.
Tunisian prime minister Zine El Abidine Ben Ali deposed and replaced President Habib Bourguiba by declaring him medically unfit for the duties of the office.
Spanish conquistador Hernán Cortés entered Tenochtitlan where Aztec tlatoani Moctezuma II welcomed him with great pomp as would befit a returning god.

The provinces of the Habsburg Netherlands signed the Pacification of Ghent, to make peace with the rebelling provinces Holland and Zeeland, and also to form an alliance to drive the occupying Spanish out of the country.
The Bodleian Library, one of Europe's oldest libraries, opened at the University of Oxford.

Thirty Years' War: An army of 15,000 Bohemians and mercenaries were routed by 27,000 men of the combined armies of the Holy Roman Empire and of the Catholic League at the Battle of White Mountain near Prague.
In South Hadley, Massachusetts, U.S., Mary Lyon founded a seminary for women that became Mount Holyoke College, the first of the Seven Sisters group of colleges.

American Civil War: USS San Jacinto stopped RMS Trent (depicted) and arrested two Confederate envoys en route to Europe, sparking a major diplomatic crisis between the United Kingdom and the United States.
Despite racial divisions, black and white union members united in a general strike in New Orleans.
German physicist Wilhelm Röntgen produced and detected electromagnetic radiation in a wavelength range known today as X-ray.
Adolf Hitler, Erich Ludendorff and other members of the Kampfbund started the Beer Hall Putsch, a failed attempt to seize power in Weimar Germany.
Georg Elser unsuccessfully attempted to assassinate Adolf Hitler with a time bomb, but killed eight people and injured sixty-two others instead.
The North African Campaign of the Second World War: Operation Torch began when American and British forces invaded French North Africa.
The United Kingdom split the Chagos Archipelago from Mauritius and the islands of Aldabra, Farquhar and Desroches from the Seychelles to form the British Indian Ocean Territory.
The United Kingdom split the Chagos Archipelago from Mauritius and the islands of Aldabra, Farquhar and Desroches from the Seychelles to form the British Indian Ocean Territory.
HBO, the oldest and longest continuously operating pay television service in the United States, began broadcasting to 325 subscribers.
The Government of India announced the demonetisation of certain banknotes, causing prolonged cash shortages in the weeks that followed and significant disruption throughout the economy.
Trần Thánh Tông, the second emperor of Vietnam's Trần dynasty, took up the title of retired emperor, but continued to co-rule with his son Nhân Tông for eleven more years.
A law was passed that confined most of Venice's glassmaking industry to nearby Murano.
The Australian military withdrew from their "war against emus" in Western Australia, due to negative press coverage of the operation.
The Shunzhi Emperor (portrait shown), the third emperor of the Qing dynasty, was enthroned in Beijing after the collapse of the Ming dynasty as the first Qing emperor to rule over China.
En route from San Francisco to Honolulu, Pan Am Flight 7 crashed into the Pacific Ocean due to unknown causes, killing all 44 people on board.
Vietnam War: In the Battle of Gang Toi, one of the earliest battles between the two sides, Viet Cong forces repelled an Australian attack.
Former Massachusetts attorney general Edward Brooke became the first African American elected to the United States Senate since Reconstruction.
English rock group Led Zeppelin released their fourth album, which became one of the best-selling albums worldwide.
British peer Lord Lucan disappeared without a trace, a day after allegedly murdering Sandra Rivett, his children's nanny.
A Provisional Irish Republican Army bomb exploded during a Remembrance Sunday ceremony in Enniskillen, Northern Ireland, killing 12 people and injuring 63 others.
German newspaper Der Spiegel publishes a report by the Federal Intelligence Service accusing figures in Liechtenstein of cooperating with organized crime.
Second Nagorno-Karabakh War: Azerbaijani forces defeated the self-proclaimed Republic of Artsakh in the Battle of Shusha, reclaiming the town after 28 years.
Arab–Byzantine wars: Having been the target of many raids by the Emirate of Aleppo, Byzantine forces led by Leo Phokas the Younger ambushed the Hamdanids and annihilated their army.
After his coronation as king of Sweden, Christian II gave the order to execute nearly 100 people, mostly noblemen, despite promises of general amnesty.
The Italian invasion of Greece failed as outnumbered Greek units repulsed the Italians at the Battle of Elaia–Kalamas.
Typhoon Haiyan made landfall in the Visayas region of the Philippines, killing at least 6,300 people, making it the deadliest Philippine typhoon recorded in modern history.
Great Britain, France and Spain signed the Treaty of Seville to end the Anglo-Spanish War, despite the underlying tensions being left unresolved.
The coup of 18 Brumaire led by Emmanuel Joseph Sieyès and Napoleon deposed the French government, replacing the Directory with the Consulate.
The first documented Canadian football match was played at University College, University of Toronto.
Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the last shogun of Japan, tendered his resignation to the Emperor Meiji.
The largest fire in Boston's history began, eventually destroying more than 750 buildings and causing $73.5 million in damage.
A major earthquake struck Zagreb and destroyed many buildings, including its cathedral.
German emperor Wilhelm II abdicated, Prince Maximilian of Baden resigned as Chancellor, and Philipp Scheidemann proclaimed the Weimar Republic.
In the Northeast blackout of 1965, several U.S. states and parts of Canada were hit by a series of power outages lasting up to 13½ hours.
French comic book heroes Valérian and Laureline first appeared in Pilote magazine.
With the passing of the Human Rights Act, the European Convention on Human Rights was incorporated into United Kingdom law.
Suicide bombers attacked three hotels in Amman, Jordan, killing a total of about 60 people and injuring at least 115 others.
The European Space Agency launched the Venus Express mission (artist's impression pictured) from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, the first long-term observation of the Venusian atmosphere.
Mary Jane Kelly, widely believed to be the fifth and final victim of the notorious unidentified serial killer Jack the Ripper, was murdered in London.
World War I: Off the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, the Australian light cruiser Sydney sank Emden, the last active German warship in the Indian Ocean, at the Battle of Cocos.

Kristallnacht began as SA stormtroopers and civilians destroyed and ransacked Jewish homes, businesses and synagogues in Germany and Austria, resulting in at least 90 deaths and the deportation of 30,000 men to concentration camps.
World War II: A covert Sicherheitsdienst operation captured two British agents of the Secret Intelligence Service near Venlo in the Netherlands.
The first issue of Rolling Stone, an American magazine focusing on music, politics and popular culture, was published.
East German official Günter Schabowski mistakenly announced the immediate opening of the inner German border, resulting in the fall of the Berlin Wall that night (border crossing pictured).
Bosnian War: Croatian Defence Council forces destroyed the Stari Most, a 16th-century bridge crossing the river Neretva in the city of Mostar (rebuilt bridge pictured).
A tram derailment in Croydon, London, killed seven people.
Pakistani prime minister Imran Khan inaugurated the Kartarpur Corridor, a visa-free border crossing connecting the Gurdwara Darbar Sahib to the India–Pakistan border.
USS Alligator engaged three pirate schooners off the coast of Cuba in one of the West Indies anti-piracy operations of the United States.
A severe blizzard reached its maximum intensity in the Great Lakes Basin of North America, destroying 19 ships and 68,300 tons of cargo, and killing more than 250 people.
The government of the Azerbaijan Democratic Republic adopted a tricolour national flag, which is again in use today, with slight modifications, by the present-day Republic of Azerbaijan.
At age 22, Garry Kasparov became the then-youngest World Chess Champion by defeating then-champion Anatoly Karpov.
The Alabama Crimson Tide and LSU Tigers football teams, both with undefeated records thus far that season, played in a "Game of the Century".
The Ottoman Empire under Sultan Murad II defeated the Polish and Hungarian armies under Władysław III of Poland and John Hunyadi at the Battle of Varna in the final battle of the Crusade of Varna.
William Franklin, the last colonial governor of New Jersey, signed a charter establishing Queen's College, now Rutgers University.
The United States Marine Corps was founded as the Continental Marines by a resolution of the Second Continental Congress during the American Revolutionary War.
The rebel army of the Donghak Peasant Revolution retreated from the Battle of Ugeumchi, marking the beginning of the fall of the revolution.
The American Legion, a veterans' mutual-aid society, held its first national convention in Minneapolis, Minnesota.
Hirohito was crowned the 124th Emperor of Japan.
Merchant Harry Winston donated the Hope Diamond, the "most famous diamond in the world", to the Smithsonian Institution.
The United Nations General Assembly adopted Resolution 3379, which equated Zionism with racism.
Longtime Bulgarian leader Todor Zhivkov resigned and was replaced by Petar Mladenov.
Fourth Crusade: The Siege of Zara, the first attack on a Catholic city by Catholic crusaders, began in present-day Zadar, Croatia.
Henry Wirz, the Confederate superintendent of Andersonville Prison, was hanged after a controversial conviction, becoming the only American Civil War officer executed for war crimes.
Journalist and explorer Henry Morton Stanley located missing missionary and explorer David Livingstone near Lake Tanganyika in present-day Tanzania.
Brazilian president Getúlio Vargas led a coup against his own constitutional government, establishing the dictatorial Estado Novo regime.
Indonesian National Revolution: Following the killing of Brigadier A. W. S. Mallaby on 30 October, British forces retaliated by attacking Surabaya (present-day logo depicted).
The children's television series Sesame Street premiered in the United States.
In Angola, the MPLA decisively defeated the FNLA in the Battle of Quifangondo, while Portugal simultaneously withdrew all its colonial and military personnel from Luanda.
SS Edmund Fitzgerald sank in Lake Superior, claiming all 29 of her crew's lives.
Nadarajah Raviraj, a prominent Sri Lankan Tamil politician and human rights lawyer, was assassinated in Colombo.

At the Ibero-American Summit in Santiago, Chile, King Juan Carlos I of Spain asked Venezuelan president Hugo Chávez "Why don't you shut up?" after Chávez repeatedly interrupted a speech by Spanish prime minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero.
The British government announced that it had removed the last land mine from the Falkland Islands, laid by Argentine forces during the 1982 Falklands War.
At the culmination of a Swedish civil war, supporters of the deposed King Sigismund III Vasa were publicly executed in the Åbo Bloodbath.

White supremacists seized power and massacred black Americans during the Wilmington massacre,(newspaper headline depicted) the only instance of a municipal government being overthrown in United States history.
An earthquake registering 7.7 Mw struck the Vrancea region of Romania.
Writer and environmental activist Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight others from the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People were executed by the Nigerian military regime led by Sani Abacha.
A skirmish occurred between South Korean and North Korean naval ships off Daecheong Island in the Yellow Sea.
The Fourth Lateran Council convened in Rome, during which the Catholic doctrine of transubstantiation was defined.
During the Italian Wars of 1499–1504, Louis XII of France and Ferdinand II of Aragon signed a secret treaty to divide the Mezzogiorno between themselves.
German polymath Gottfried Leibniz employed integral calculus for the first time to find the area under the graph of the function y = f(x).
The Virginia Military Institute, currently the oldest state military college in the United States, was founded.
Washington, named in honor of the first U.S. president, was admitted to the United States as the 42nd state.
Route 66, the "Main Street of America" running from Chicago to Los Angeles, was established.
World War II: The German auxiliary cruiser Atlantis captured top-secret documents from SS Automedon that later influenced Japan's decision to enter the war.

World War II: The Allies defeated the Axis at the Second Battle of El Alamein, Egypt, turning the tide in the North African Campaign by ending Axis hopes of taking control of the Suez Canal and thus gaining access east to the Middle Eastern oil fields.
American Revolutionary War: British forces and their Iroquois allies attacked a fort and the village of Cherry Valley, New York, killing 14 soldiers and 30 civilians.
War of 1812: British–Canadian forces repelled an American attack at the Battle of Crysler's Farm, forcing the United States to give up their attempt to capture Montreal.
Australian bushranger and outlaw Ned Kelly was hanged in Melbourne, in spite of sympathizers holding rallies for his reprieve.
The armistice between the German Empire and the Allies was signed in a railway carriage in the Forest of Compiègne of France (signatories pictured).
Józef Piłsudski, appointed the commander-in-chief of Polish forces by the Regency Council, was entrusted with the creation of a national government for the newly independent Poland.
The plan for the United States Numbered Highway System was approved by the American Association of State Highway Officials.
The Shrine of Remembrance, a memorial to all Australians who have served in war, opened in Melbourne.
During a constitutional crisis, Governor-General Sir John Kerr dismissed Prime Minister Gough Whitlam's government and dissolved the Parliament of Australia for a double-dissolution election.
The House of Lords Act was given royal assent, removing most hereditary peers from the British House of Lords.
After 30 years in power, Maumoon Abdul Gayoom was succeeded by Mohamed Nasheed as president of the Maldives.
War of the Third Coalition: French, Austrian and Russian units suffered heavy losses at the Battle of Dürenstein.
In London, the Cenotaph was unveiled and the Unknown Warrior was buried in Westminster Abbey in remembrance of the First World War.
Second World War: The Royal Navy launched the first all-aircraft ship-to-ship naval attack in history against the Italians in the Battle of Taranto.
A coup attempt by the Army of the Republic of Vietnam against President Ngô Đình Diệm was crushed after he falsely promised reform, allowing loyalists to rescue him.
Rhodesia, led by Prime Minister Ian Smith, unilaterally declared independence from the United Kingdom.
At the age of 13, Lothair of France (depicted) was crowned king of West Francia.

Mortimer Durand, Foreign Secretary of British India, and Abdur Rahman Khan, Amir of Afghanistan, signed the Durand Line Agreement, establishing what is now the international border between Afghanistan and Pakistan.
In a referendum, 79 percent of voters opted to keep Norway a monarchy, paving the way for Haakon VII to take the throne.
Leon Trotsky was expelled from the Communist Party, leaving Joseph Stalin in undisputed control of the Soviet Union.
The San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge, connecting San Francisco and Oakland, California across San Francisco Bay, opened to traffic.

The International Military Tribunal for the Far East sentenced former prime minister Hideki Tojo and other military and government officials from the former Empire of Japan to death for committing war crimes during World War II.
American journalist Seymour Hersh published his exposé of the My Lai massacre, which later earned him the Pulitzer Prize for International Reporting.
President of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev issued a decree "about introducing national currency of Republic of Kazakhstan", leading to the establishment of the Kazakhstani tenge three days later.
Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi tendered his resignation in part due to his perceived failure to tackle Italy's debt crisis.
William Heffelfinger was paid $500 by the Allegheny Athletic Association, becoming the first professional American football player.
The Corozal, the most powerful dredger built to that time, was launched in London for service in construction of the Panama Canal.
Eight months after perishing during the ill-fated Terra Nova Expedition, the bodies of Robert Falcon Scott and his companions were discovered on the Ross Ice Shelf in Antarctica.
The British ocean liner SS Vestris sank in the western Atlantic Ocean, killing 111 people.
At the request of the Government of Western Australia, the Australian military officially resumed fighting the Emu War after their prior withdrawal.
World War II: Soviet foreign minister Vyacheslav Molotov arrived in Berlin to discuss the possibility of the Soviet Union joining the Axis powers.

World War II: The Naval Battle of Guadalcanal, the decisive engagement in a series of sea battles between Allied and Japanese forces during the months-long Guadalcanal campaign in the Solomon Islands, began.
Second World War: In Operation Catechism, the Royal Air Force sank the German battleship Tirpitz (video featured) near Tromsø, Norway, killing about 1,000 sailors on board.
Suez Crisis: During an invasion of Rafah, Israeli soldiers shot and killed an estimated 111 Palestinian refugees and local inhabitants.
The Oregon Highway Division unsuccessfully attempted to destroy a rotting beached sperm whale near Florence, Oregon, with dynamite.
The first episode of Last of the Summer Wine, the longest-running television sitcom in history, premiered on the BBC.
Indonesian forces opened fire on student demonstrators protesting the occupation of East Timor in the capital Dili, killing at least 250 people.
A Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 and a Kazakhstan Airlines Ilyushin Il-76 collided in mid-air near New Delhi, killing 349 people, the deadliest such collision in history.
American Airlines Flight 587 crashed into residential buildings five minutes after takeoff from John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York, killing a total of 265 people.

Although the Georgian government declared it illegal, South Ossetia held a referendum on independence, with more than 99 percent of voters in favour of preserving the region's status as a de facto independent state.
The European Space Agency's lander Philae  touched down on 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko, becoming the first spacecraft to land on a comet.
Led by the voivode Basarab I, Wallachian forces defeated the Hungarian army in an ambush at the Battle of Posada (depicted).
The Kingdom of Italy and the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes signed the Treaty of Rapallo to establish national borders east of the Adriatic Sea.
World War II: Free French forces captured Gabon from Vichy France.
The deadliest tropical cyclone in history made landfall on the coast of East Pakistan (present-day Bangladesh), killing at least 250,000 people.
An explosion in the Shahid Modarres missile base led to the deaths of 17 members of the Revolutionary Guards, including Hassan Tehrani Moghaddam, a key figure in Iran's missile program.
Scottish surgeon James Braid observed a demonstration of animal magnetism, which inspired him to study the subject he eventually called hypnotism.
Great Britain defeated France at the Parc des Princes in Paris to win the first Rugby League World Cup.
The steamship SS Yarmouth Castle burned and sank about 60 miles (100 km) northwest of Nassau, Bahamas, killing about 90 people.
The Vietnam Veterans Memorial was dedicated in Constitution Gardens in Washington, D.C.
Hans-Adam II, reigning Prince of Liechtenstein, took the throne upon the death of his father.
A man began shooting people indiscriminately in Aramoana, New Zealand, killing thirteen people in the country's deadliest criminal shooting.
China Northern Airlines Flight 6901 crashed upon its approach to Ürümqi Airport, killing twelve people.
Joseph Estrada became the first president of the Philippines to be impeached after he was accused of taking a sum of 400 million pesos in bribes from illegal gambling sources.
An explosion hit the Batasang Pambansa Complex in Quezon City, Philippines, killing Congressman Wahab Akbar and five others.
King Æthelred II ordered the massacre of all Danes in England.
A British flotilla arrived at Ras Al Khaimah and launched an amphibious assault on the town, as a part of the Persian Gulf campaign of 1809.
Zaian War: Zaian Berber tribesmen routed French forces at the Battle of El Herri in Morocco.
The Holland Tunnel opened, connecting Manhattan with Jersey City under the Hudson River.
A man wielding a dagger was subdued as he was about to attack Sanzō Nosaka, the chairman of the Japanese Communist Party.
Arab–Israeli conflict: In response to a Fatah landmine incident, the Israeli military conducted a large cross-border assault on the Jordanian-controlled West Bank village of Samu.
Ronald DeFeo Jr. killed six members of his family in Amityville, New York, events that later inspired the book The Amityville Horror and a subsequent media franchise.
South Korean boxer Kim Duk-koo suffered fatal brain injuries during a match with American Ray Mancini in Las Vegas, leading to significant rule changes in the sport.

The High Court of Australia ruled in Dietrich v The Queen that, although there is no absolute right to have publicly funded counsel, a judge should grant any request for an adjournment or stay in most circumstances in which an accused is unrepresented.
First English Civil War: Royalist forces engaged the much larger Parliamentarian army at the Battle of Turnham Green near Turnham Green, Middlesex.
American Revolutionary War: American forces captured Montreal without significant opposition as part of the Invasion of Quebec.
Walt Disney's Fantasia, the first commercial film shown with stereophonic sound, premiered at the Broadway Theatre in New York City.
The volcano Nevado del Ruiz erupted, causing a volcanic mudslide that buried the town of Armero, Colombia, killing approximately 23,000 people.
Coordinated terrorist attacks in Paris perpetrated by the Islamic State killed 130 people and injured 413 others.
Frederick of Isenberg was executed for the murder of his cousin Engelbert of Berg, the Archbishop of Cologne.
Scottish travel writer James Bruce discovered what he believed to be the source of the Nile.
French invasion of Russia: The French defeat at the Battle of Smoliani forced them to abandon the "Dwina Line", their northern flank in Russia.
Bolívar's War: Colombian seamstress Policarpa Salavarrieta was executed  in Bogotá for working as a spy for the revolutionary forces in New Granada.
The Communist Party of Spain was founded in Madrid from the merger of two prior organizations
Second World War: The cathedral and much of the city centre of Coventry, England, were destroyed by the Luftwaffe during the Coventry Blitz.
Al Martino's song "Here in My Heart" became the first number one on the UK Singles Chart.
Vietnam War: The United States Army and the People's Army of Vietnam engaged at the Battle of Ia Drang.
With the signing of the Madrid Accords, Spain agreed to withdraw its presence from the territory of Spanish Sahara.
Cesar Climaco, mayor of Zamboanga City, the Philippines, was assassinated by an unknown gunman.
NASA's Mariner 9 reached Mars, en route to becoming the first spacecraft to orbit another planet.
Germany and Poland signed the German–Polish Border Treaty, confirming their border at the Oder–Neisse line, which was originally defined by the Potsdam Agreement in 1945.
A train derailed in Eckwersheim, France, while performing trials on the high-speed rail line LGV Est.
Moby-Dick, an epic novel by American writer Herman Melville, was first published in the United States.
World War II: German troops, aided by local auxiliaries, murdered nine thousand residents of the Słonim Ghetto in a single day.
Second World War: After suffering torpedo damage the previous day, the British aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal sank as she was being towed to Gibraltar for repairs.
Ruby Bridges and the McDonogh Three became the first black children to attend an all-white elementary school in Louisiana as part of the New Orleans school desegregation crisis.
Apollo 12 launched from the Kennedy Space Center, later becoming the second crewed flight to land on the Moon.
Music producer Frank Farian admitted that the German R&B duo Milli Vanilli did not sing the vocals on their album Girl You Know It's True.
Croatian War of Independence: Croatian naval commandos attacked the Yugoslav patrol boat Mukos, starting the Battle of the Dalmatian Channels.
In poor conditions caused by Cyclone Forrest, Vietnam Airlines Flight 474 crashed near Nha Trang, killing 30 people.
As a result of budget conflicts between President Bill Clinton and the United States Congress led by Newt Gingrich, the federal government was forced to shut down non-essential services.
Astronomers Michael E. Brown, Chad Trujillo, and David L. Rabinowitz discovered the trans-Neptunian object Sedna.
German astronomer Gottfried Kirch discovered the Great Comet of 1680, the first comet to be discovered by telescope.
Aviator Eugene Burton Ely performed the first takeoff from a ship, flying from a makeshift deck on USS Birmingham in Hampton Roads, Virginia.
American physicist Theodore Maiman was given a patent for his ruby laser systems, the world's first laser.
Southern Airways Flight 932, chartered by the Marshall University football team, crashed into a hill near Ceredo, West Virginia, killing all 75 people on board.
Red Bull Racing's Sebastian Vettel won the Drivers' Championship after winning the final race of the season, becoming the youngest Formula One champion.
Justin II became Byzantine emperor, having allegedly been chosen by his uncle Justinian I as his successor on his deathbed.
A 1,500-strong Swiss force ambushed a group of Austrian soldiers of the Holy Roman Empire on the shores of the Ägerisee.
Prince William of Orange landed at Brixham in Devon, on his way to depose his uncle and father-in-law King James II, the last Catholic monarch of England.
The semi-autonomous Free City of Danzig was created in order to give Poland access to a well-sized seaport.
The Commonwealth of the Philippines was officially established, with Manuel L. Quezon inaugurated as its president.

Vietnam War: American forces launched Operation Commando Hunt, a large-scale bombing campaign to prevent the People's Army of Vietnam from transporting personnel and supplies along the Ho Chi Minh trail.
Intel released the 4004, the world's first commercially available microprocessor, capable of executing approximately 60,000 instructions per second.
René Lévesque and the Parti Québécois took power to become the first Quebec government of the 20th century that was clearly in favour of independence from Canada.
Turkish Cypriots on the northeastern portion of Cyprus declared the creation of a new state known as the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, which currently remains recognised only by Turkey.

Northern Ireland peace process: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, and the Irish Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald signed the Anglo-Irish Agreement, giving the Irish Government an advisory role in Northern Ireland's government.
Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat proclaimed the creation of the State of Palestine as "the state of Palestinians wherever they may be".
Jiang Zemin was replaced by Hu Jintao as General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, succeeding as the paramount leader of China.
The chapel of the newly constructed Castellania in Valletta, Malta, was consecrated.
Sponsored by Greek businessman Evangelos Zappas, the first modern revival of the Olympic Games took place in Athens.
Brazilian emperor Pedro II was overthrown in a coup led by Deodoro da Fonseca, while the country was proclaimed a republic.
During a general strike in Guayaquil, Ecuador, police and military fired into a crowd, killing at least 300 people.
The Holocaust: In the Romani Holocaust, Nazi official Heinrich Himmler ordered that the Romani were to be put "on the same level as Jews and placed in concentration camps".
Two men murdered a family in Holcomb, Kansas; the events became the subject of Truman Capote's non-fiction novel In Cold Blood, a pioneering work of the true crime genre.
The Soviet spacecraft Buran, a reusable vehicle built in response to NASA's Space Shuttle program, was launched, uncrewed, on its only flight.
Xi Jinping replaced Hu Jintao as General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, succeeding as the paramount leader of China.
Penda of Mercia and Æthelhere of East Anglia were defeated by Oswiu of Northumbria at the Battle of the Winwaed in Yorkshire, England.

American Civil War: Union army general William Tecumseh Sherman began his March to the Sea, inflicting significant damage to property and infrastructure using scorched-earth tactics on his way from Atlanta to Savannah, Georgia.
As a result of numerous atrocities in the territory, the Congo Free State was annexed to Belgium to form the Belgian Congo.
Fountain of Time, in Chicago's Washington Park, was dedicated as a tribute to 100 years of peace between the United States and Great Britain following the Treaty of Ghent.
Edoardo Agnelli, son of the industrialist patriarch Gianni Agnelli, was found dead under a bridge on the outskirts of Turin, Italy.
Several Jews and conversos were executed in Toledo, Spain, for the alleged ritual murder of an infant, who was later revered as the Holy Child of La Guardia.
War of the Third Coalition: At the Battle of Schöngrabern, Russian forces under Pyotr Bagration delayed the pursuit by French troops under Joachim Murat.
Explorer David Livingstone became the first European to see Victoria Falls, one of the largest waterfalls in the world, on what is now the Zambia–Zimbabwe border.
The United States' National Rifle Association was first chartered in the state of New York by William Conant Church and George Wood Wingate.
Two years after the failed attempt by the Five Civilized Tribes in the Indian Territory to achieve U.S. statehood, they joined with the Oklahoma Territory to become the 46th state to enter the union.
Qantas, Australia's national airline, was founded as Queensland and Northern Territory Aerial Services.
The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) (flag depicted) was founded.
The Arecibo message, devised by Frank Drake and Carl Sagan and carrying basic information about humanity, was transmitted towards the globular star cluster M13.
Eight employees of Universidad Centroamericana "José Simeón Cañas" in San Salvador, including six Catholic priests, were murdered by a Salvadoran Army "death squad".
The second edition of the Code of Justinian, a codification of Roman law by Byzantine emperor Justinian I, was published.
With the help of Stephen III and Stephen Báthory, Vlad the Impaler ousted Basarab the Old and became the ruler of Wallachia for the third time.
Spanish conquest of Peru: Conquistador Francisco Pizarro orchestrated a surprise attack in Cajamarca, capturing the Inca emperor, Atahualpa.
King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden was killed at the Battle of Lützen during the Thirty Years' War.
American Revolutionary War: Fort Washington on Manhattan was captured from the Patriots by British and Hessian units.
World War I: Austro-Hungarian forces launched an assault against Serbian defensive positions at the Kolubara river, beginning the Battle of Kolubara.
World War II: Operation Queen commenced with one of the heaviest Allied tactical bombings of the war, attacking German targets in the Rur valley.
The Sound of Music, a musical by Rodgers and Hammerstein based on The Story of the Trapp Family Singers, opened on Broadway at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre.
U.S. president Richard Nixon signed an act authorizing the construction of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline to transport oil from the Beaufort Sea to the Gulf of Alaska.

In Suffolk, England, a local man found the largest hoard of Roman silver and gold in Britain (sample pictured), including the largest collection of 4th- and 5th-century gold and silver coins ever discovered within the former Roman Empire.
Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng, released on ostensibly medical grounds after spending eighteen years in prison, was deported to the United States.
The first case of SARS, a zoonotic respiratory coronavirus disease, was recorded in Guangdong, China.
The El Dorado Fire in California, United States, was extinguished after 71 days, having destroyed 20 structures and killed one firefighter.
American Revolutionary War: A Dutch fort on Sint Eustatius fired The First Salute to an American brig, marking the first international recognition of the American flag.
After a five-day trial following the North-West Rebellion, Louis Riel, a Canadian Métis leader and "Father of Manitoba", was hanged for high treason.
Swiss chemist Albert Hofmann first synthesized the psychedelic drug LSD in Basel, Switzerland.
Aeroflot Flight 2230 crashed after takeoff from Koltsovo Airport, Russia, killing all 107 people aboard.
About 30 million people watched the fictional couple Luke Spencer and Laura Webber wed on the television show General Hospital in the highest-rated hour in American soap opera history.
Emperor Kanmu of Japan moved his residence from Nara to Kyoto, beginning the Heian period.
The Sultanate of Sulu was established on the Sulu Archipelago off the coast of Mindanao in the Philippines.
The U.S. Congress convened in Washington, D.C. for the first time in the partially completed Capitol Building.
Giuseppe Verdi's first opera, Oberto, premiered at La Scala in Milan.
The Suez Canal opened, allowing shipping to travel between Europe and Asia via the Mediterranean Sea and the Red Sea.
H. H. Holmes, one of the first modern serial killers, was arrested in Boston after killing at least nine people.
Influenced by the result of the Russo-Japanese War, the Empire of Japan and the Korean Empire signed the Eulsa Treaty, effectively depriving Korea of its diplomatic sovereignty.
John F. Kennedy and Dwight D. Eisenhower dedicated Dulles International Airport, one of three major airports in the Baltimore–Washington, D.C. area.
Cold War: Representatives from the Soviet Union and the United States met in Helsinki to begin the SALT I negotiations aimed at limiting the number of strategic weapons on both sides.
The Soviet Union's Lunokhod 1 landed on the Moon to become the first roving remote-controlled robot to operate on another celestial body.
American inventor Douglas Engelbart received the patent for the first computer mouse.
Students at the Athens Polytechnic conclude a strike against the Greek junta, which lasted four days.
Police quelled a student demonstration in Prague, sparking the Velvet Revolution aimed at overthrowing the Czechoslovakian communist government.
General Sani Abacha ousted Ernest Shonekan to become chairman of the Provisional Ruling Council of Nigeria.
In Manfalut, Egypt, a school bus was hit by a train, killing at least 50 children.
John Balliol was chosen to be King of Scots over Robert de Brus.
Elizabeth I  became Queen of England and of Ireland, marking the beginning of the Elizabethan era.
French Revolutionary Wars: French forces won the Battle of Arcole in a manoeuvre to cut the Austrians' line of retreat.
World War II: Hjalmar Siilasvuo ordered Finnish forces to halt their assault against Soviet forces near Salla, concluding Operation Arctic Fox.

NBC controversially cut away from an American football game between the Oakland Raiders and New York Jets to broadcast Heidi, causing viewers in the Eastern United States to miss the game's dramatic ending.
Walt Disney Pictures released The Little Mermaid to theatres, beginning the Disney Renaissance.
Sixty-two people were killed by Islamist terrorists outside Deir el-Bahari (temple pictured) in Luxor, one of Egypt's top tourist attractions.
Administrators at the University of East Anglia's Climatic Research Unit discovered that their servers had been hacked, and thousands of emails and files on climate change had been stolen.
An outbreak of 77 confirmed tornadoes occurred in seven U.S. states; it became the largest November tornado outbreak in Illinois and Indiana.
Sigismund III Vasa, who was already King of Poland, succeeded his father John III as King of Sweden.
Rioting broke out in Bombay, India, during the visit of Edward, Prince of Wales, leading to at least 58 deaths.
World War II: Australian forces launched an assault on Sattelberg, New Guinea, against Japanese forces, initiating the Battle of Sattelberg.
The 14th Dalai Lama assumed full temporal power as ruler of Tibet at the age of 15.

Tatarstan Airlines Flight 363 crashed during an aborted landing at Kazan International Airport, Russia, killing all 50 people on board and leading to the revocation of the airline's operating certificate.
Pope Boniface VIII issued the Papal bull Unam sanctam, proclaiming "there is one holy Catholic and Apostolic Church, outside of which there is neither salvation nor remission of sins".
William Tell, a legendary marksman in Switzerland, was said to have successfully shot an apple on his son's head with a single bolt from his crossbow.
St. Peter's Basilica, one of four major basilicas of Rome, was consecrated on the anniversary of that of the previous church in 326.

Napoleonic Wars: During Napoleon's invasion of Russia, Marshal Michel Ney's leadership in the Battle of Krasnoi earned him the nickname "the bravest of the brave" despite the overwhelming French defeat.
Soprano Marie Selika Williams became the first African-American artist to perform at the White House.
Prince Carl of Denmark became Haakon VII, the first King of Norway after the personal union between Sweden and Norway was dissolved.
Walt Disney's Steamboat Willie, the first completely post-produced synchronized sound animated cartoon, was released.
Second World War: The Royal Air Force began its bombing campaign against Berlin.
The first push-button telephone was made available to Bell System customers.
Calvin and Hobbes, a comic strip by Bill Watterson that was at its height one of the most popular in the world, was first published.
In Ukraine's worst mining accident, more than 100 workers were killed in a methane explosion at the Zasyadko coal mine.
Pope Tawadros II of Alexandria took office as the 118th Pope of the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria.
The Siege of Godes­berg, the first major siege of the Cologne War, began.
Napoleonic Wars: In the Bay of Bengal, a French frigate squadron captured three ships carrying recruits for the armies of the East India Company.
At the Polish embassy in Moscow, a phrase in an address by Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev was translated into English as "We will bury you", prompting Western envoys to leave the room.
Solomon Islands ratified the adoption of a new flag.
Jim Jones led more than 900 members of the Peoples Temple to mass murder/suicide in Jonestown, Guyana, hours after some of its members assassinated U.S. Congressman Leo Ryan.
The current flag of Uzbekistan was adopted, making the country the first newly independent republic in Central Asia to choose a new flag.
Croatian War of Independence: The Yugoslav People's Army captured the Croatian city of Vukovar, ending an 87-day siege.

Texas A&M University's Aggie Bonfire collapsed (aftermath pictured), killing 12 people and injuring 27 others, and causing the university to officially declare a hiatus on the 90-year-old annual event.
With its ruling in Goodridge v. Department of Public Health, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court made the state the first in the U.S. to legalize same-sex marriage.
Two Palestinian men attacked the praying congregants of a synagogue in Jerusalem with axes, knives, and a gun, resulting in eight deaths, including the attackers themselves.
Cyclone Numa, a rare "medicane", made landfall in Greece to become the worst weather event that the country had experienced since 1977.
Otto IV, Holy Roman Emperor, was ex­com­mu­ni­cated by Pope Innocent III after Otto commanded him to annul the Concordat of Worms.
"The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County" was published, becoming the first great success of American author Mark Twain.
American suffragist Susan B. Anthony was arrested and later fined $100 for having voted in the presidential election two weeks earlier.
An underground fire killed 31 people at King's Cross St Pancras tube station in London.
The sandbox video game Minecraft exited beta with the official release of version 1.0.
Council of Clermont
Christopher Columbus became the first European to land on Puerto Rico, naming it San Juan Bautista after John the Baptist.
The University of Warsaw, the largest university in Poland, was established as Congress Poland found itself a territory without a university.
The Holocaust: Inmates at the Janowska concentration camp near what is now Lviv, Ukraine, staged a failed uprising, after which the SS liquidated the camp, resulting in at least 6,000 deaths.
The National Review, one of the most widely read and influential American conservative magazines, was first published.
TAP Air Portugal Flight 425 crashed while attempting to land at Madeira Airport in Funchal, Madeira, killing more than 130 people on board.
The first line of the Bucharest Metro, the M1 Line, opened from Timpuri Noi to Semănătoarea in Bucharest, Romania.
The first National Lottery draw in the United Kingdom was held, with seven winners sharing a prize of £5,874,778.
Shenzhou 1, China's first unmanned test flight of the Shenzhou spacecraft, was launched from the Jiuquan Satellite Lach Center in Alxa League, Inner Mongolia.
Malice at the Palace, A fight that broke out between fans and players at basketball game that saw the Indiana Pacers and Detroit Pistons play eachother.
The Mayflower (depicted), which brought the Pilgrims from England to the New World, sighted Cape Cod.
The United States and Great Britain signed the Jay Treaty, the basis for ten years of peaceful trade between the two nations.
Temenggong Abdul Rahman of Johor and Sultan Hussein Shah of Johor ceded the governance of Singapore to the British East India Company.
American Civil War: Confederate forces began the Siege of Knoxville against Union fortifications, surrounding most of the city.
The Union of the Right, a coalition of right-wing parties, won the majority of seats in the 1933 Spanish general election, the first election in the country with suffrage extended to women.
World War II: The Australian light cruiser HMAS Sydney and the German auxiliary cruiser Kormoran destroyed each other in the Indian Ocean.
Playing for Santos against Vasco da Gama in Rio de Janeiro, Brazilian footballer Pelé scored his thousandth goal.
Mexican singer Luis Miguel released the album Romance, which led to a revival of interest in bolero music.

The Greek oil tanker Prestige split in two and sank off the coast of Galicia after spilling 420 thousand barrels (17.8 million US gallons) of oil, in the worst environmental disaster in Spanish and Portuguese history.
A double suicide bombing at the Iranian embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, killed 23 people and injured at least 160 others.
American Civil War: U.S. president Abraham Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address at the dedication of the Soldiers' National Cemetery in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.
World War II: Soviet troops launched Operation Uranus at the Battle of Stalingrad with the goal of encircling Axis forces, turning the tide of the battle in their favour.
The first of five summits between Soviet general secretary Mikhail Gorbachev and U.S. president Ronald Reagan began in Geneva.
Iraq War: A group of United States Marines massacred 25 people in the town of Haditha.
The first of four explosions occurred at the Pike River Mine in the West Coast in New Zealand's worst mining disaster in nearly a century.
Zumbi, the last of the leaders of Quilombo dos Palmares in early Brazil, was executed.

Anglo-French blockade of the Río de la Plata: The Argentine Confederation was defeated in the Battle of Vuelta de Obligado, but the losses ultimately made the United Kingdom and France give up the blockade.
While discussing how to promote the newspaper L'Auto, sports journalist Géo Lefèvre came up with the idea of holding a cycling race that later became known as the Tour de France.
Francisco I. Madero promulgated the Plan of San Luis Potosí, starting a revolt against President Porfirio Díaz that marked the beginning of the Mexican Revolution.
Spanish Civil War: Founder of the fascist Falange Española José Antonio Primo de Rivera was executed by the republican government.
World War II: The Battle of Tarawa began with American forces landing on Tarawa Atoll in the Gilbert Islands and suffering heavy fire from the Japanese.
The Slánský trial, a show trial against Czech General Secretary Rudolf Slánský and 13 other members of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia, was held.
An explosion at a coal mine in West Virginia, U.S., killed 78 people and served as the catalyst for several new laws that were passed to protect miners.
An oil platform drilling accident caused Lake Peigneur in the U.S. state of Louisiana to drain into a salt mine underneath, creating a whirlpool that sucked down the lake's entire contents.
The assembly of the International Space Station began when Zarya, its first module, was launched from Baikonur Cosmodrome, Kazakhstan.
Diocletian became Roman emperor, eventually establishing reforms that ended the Crisis of the Third Century.
War of Jenkins' Ear: A British naval force arrived at the settlement of Portobello in the Spanish Main, capturing it the next day.
American Revolutionary War: The Battle of Fort Lee saw the invasion of New Jersey by British and Hessian forces and the subsequent general retreat of the Continental Army.
The Nuremberg trials (defendants pictured) of 24 leading Nazis involved in the Holocaust and various war crimes during World War II began in Nuremberg, Germany.
Princess Elizabeth, daughter of King George VI, married Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten, who was given the title Duke of Edinburgh.
A group of Native American activists began a 19-month occupation (graffiti pictured) of Alcatraz Island in San Francisco Bay.
Armed insurgents attacked and took over the Masjid al-Haram in Mecca, declaring that one of their leaders was the Mahdi, the prophesied redeemer of Islam.
First Nagorno-Karabakh War: An Azerbaijani military helicopter carrying a peacekeeping mission team was shot down in Nagorno-Karabakh, disrupting ongoing peace talks.
In accordance with the Lusaka Protocol, the Angolan government signed a ceasefire with UNITA rebels in a failed attempt to end the Angolan Civil War.

The American whaleship Essex sank 2,000 nautical miles (3,700 km) west of the western coast of South America after it was attacked by a sperm whale, an event which inspired the novel Moby-Dick by Herman Melville.
First World War: The Battle of Cambrai began with British forces having initial success over Germany's Hindenburg Line.
Windows 1.0, the first version of Microsoft Windows available to the public, was released.
Andrei Chikatilo, one of the Soviet Union's most prolific serial killers, was arrested in Novocherkassk.
Suicide bombers blew up the British consulate and the headquarters of HSBC Bank in Istanbul, killing 31 people, including consul general Roger Short and actor Kerem Yılmazer.
The first successful untethered flight by humans in a hot air balloon was made by Jean-François Pilâtre de Rozier and François Laurent d'Arlandes in Paris.
Polish troops and civilians began a three-day pogrom against Jews and Christians in Lwów (now Lviv, Ukraine).
The Sino-Indian War ended after the Chinese People's Liberation Army declared a ceasefire.
A propane explosion at the Humberto Vidal shoe store in Río Piedras, San Juan, Puerto Rico, killed 33 people and wounded 69 others when the building collapsed.
Lebanese politician Pierre Amine Gemayel, a vocal critic of Syria's military presence in and political domination of Lebanon, was assassinated in Jdeideh.
U Gambira, who led Burmese monks in the failed Saffron Revolution against military rule, was sentenced to 68 years' imprisonment.
Massive protests started across Ukraine after President Viktor Yanukovych suspended signing the Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement.
Turco-Mongol conqueror Timur captured and sacked the Georgian capital Tbilisi and forced King Bagrat V to convert to Islam.
Thomas Edison announced his invention of the phonograph, a device able to record and play sound.
First Sino-Japanese War: After capturing the Chinese city of Port Arthur, the Japanese army began a massacre of the city's soldiers and civilians.
Rebecca Latimer Felton became the first woman to serve in the United States Senate, albeit for only one day.
Two trains collided near Valemount, Canada, killing 21 people; the subsequent trial brought future prime minister John Diefenbaker to greater political attention.
American disc jockey Alan Freed, who popularized the term rock and roll, was fired from WABC-AM for his role in the payola scandal.
La Ronde, the first revolving restaurant in the United States, was inaugurated.
The Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge, connecting Staten Island and Brooklyn in New York City, opened to traffic as the longest suspension bridge in the world at the time.
